TEXT.English: When populations began to organize their communities into cities, their governments became more structured and formalized. At an early stage, the ruler of the city established headquarters from which the business of running the city was conducted. In many cases, these buildings also served as the living quarters of the ruler. In wealthy cities, these facilities often expanded into immense, sprawling palaces. These richly adorned, imposing buildings were a source of civic pride, and helped to reinforce the aura of power surrounding the ruler.
TEXT.Chinese: 当人们开始在城市中聚居时，相应的政府机构也变得更有组织，更为正规。起初，城市的领袖建起指挥所并在其中发号施令。而通常这样的建筑也同时成为领袖的住处。在富庶的城市中，原有建筑往往不断重修扩建，成为占地广阔的宫殿。宫殿由于外观壮丽，装饰豪华而令市民感到自豪，并且有助于强化领袖的统治威势。

TEXT.English: A collection of imperial structures in Beijing, the Forbidden Palace stands as a testament to the Chinese architectural ingenuity and aesthetic. Ornamental gardens, terraces and fountains surround the magnificent structure, which became the capital of China in 1421. It was the residence of 24 emperors of the Ming and Qing Dynasties until the last emperor abdicated in 1911. Although the correct title for the building is the Imperial Palace, it is more widely known as the "Forbidden" Palace because ordinary people were barred from entering its grounds. With a 160-foot moat and walls 30 feet tall, there was little chance that they would get inside unwanted. The Forbidden Palace is enormous; it occupies 170 acres and contains 8,706 rooms. An estimated eight to ten thousand people lived inside the palace to serve the needs of the emperor. Today, the Forbidden Palace is a major tourist attraction, and it is still used as a symbol of Chinese sovereignty.
TEXT.Chinese: 紫禁城是位于北京的一座皇室建筑群，作为中国建筑技术与建筑风格的集中体现而闻名于世。紫禁城中殿堂宫室气势恢宏，亭台楼阁不计其数，1421年，永乐皇帝正式迁都北京。此后明清两朝的24位皇帝均居住于此，直到1911年末代皇帝宣统的退位。皇宫大内戒备森严，禁止平民百姓入内，故此称为“禁宫”。环绕紫禁城的是宽160英尺的护城河与高30英尺的城墙，外来者想要闯入难如登天。整座皇宫占地170亩，拥有大小房间8,706间。估计当时有八千至一万人生活其中，以随时服侍皇帝。在今天，紫禁城已成为一个重要旅游景点，并且仍然是中国最高统治权的象征。

TEXT.English: The Palace of Versailles began life as a hunting lodge constructed at the instructions of King Louix XIII, who enjoyed hunting in the nearby woods. In 1660, his son Louis XIV decided to turn the "chateau" into a palace. Louis XIV took up residence in 1682, and construction on the palace was completed in 1688. During Louis' lifetime this huge, ungainly, and ornate building was not only his residence, but it also housed the royal court and central bureaucracy of France. Versailles is a complex of richly appointed buildings centered in one-and-a-half square miles of fine parkland. It is surrounded by beautiful fountains, statues, and magnificent formal gardens. [PARAGRAPH:2]At the very center of the palace was, of course, Louis' bedroom, a massive and ostentatious room. At the center of the bedroom was the Royal Bed, which was surrounded by a railing, suggesting that the king did indeed hold large audiences while reclining in the bed and needed a way to keep the visitors' fingers from messing up the royal linens. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Hall of Mirrors is another impressive room in Versailles. Over 200 feet in length and 30 feet wide, the hall contains 578 mirrors and 17 ornate windows. On the ceiling Louis had painted 30 pictures showing his many triumphs and the benefits of his rule. [PARAGRAPH:2]While appearing to many a massive exercise in royal excess, Louis had good reason for constructing Versailles; with one stroke he removed the nobility and bureaucracy from the intrigues of Paris and made them more immediately responsible to him. In this way he was able to render the once powerful nobility largely impotent; great families which had once battled each other for the throne of France now found themselves instead intriguing for the privilege of attending Louis' bath. [PARAGRAPH:2]Nonetheless, Versailles was, in fact, an extraordinarily expensive building. It has been estimated that maintaining the palace and its noble denizens consumed 6%% of the entire French national budget. For a comparison, the United States' President's 2006 budget estimates that the US will take in about 2.2 trillion dollars in revenue in 2006. Six percent of that amount is 132 billion dollars. [PARAGRAPH:2]After the French Revolution and the dissolution of the monarchy, Versailles fell into disrepair and disuse. The German Army made the complex its headquarters after defeating France in the Franco-Prussian war in 1870. The building remained in decay until the 1960s, when Pierre Verlet conceived the bold idea of refurbishing Versailles to its glory days under Louis XIV. Since then the curators have managed to retrieve many of the original furnishings from across Europe.
TEXT.Chinese: 凡尔赛宫原本只是路易十三建造的猎宫，这位国王非常喜欢在附近的森林中狩猎。他的儿子路易十四在1660年决定将这座“城堡”改建为宫殿，并于1682年移驾此地，但整个工程却是在1688年完工。在路易十四有生之年，这一宏伟，庄严，华丽的建筑不仅是他的住处，同时还是法国的中央官僚机构的驻地。凡尔赛宫以一座占地1.5平方公里的，富丽堂皇的宫殿为中心。它的四周则是漂亮的喷泉、雕像以及华丽的花园。[PARAGRAPH:2]在宫殿的最中心是国王的卧室，这是一个庞大而又浮华的房间。在卧室的中央是国王的床，旁边则被栏杆围绕着，这意味着国王在此处接见臣下时，臣子们的手不能触碰到国王的卧具。[PARAGRAPH:2]镜厅是凡尔赛宫内另一个给人深刻印象的房间，它长达200英尺，宽达30英尺，其间有578面镜子和17面装饰华丽的窗户。路易十四让人在天花板上画了30幅壁画，用来夸耀自己的文治武功。[PARAGRAPH:2]尽管凡尔赛宫对于王室来说也太过豪华，但路易十四之所以这么做也有他自己的原因：他可以通过让贵族和官僚机构移居此地，从而一劳永逸地解决内部问题，让他们只对自己负责。他使原本强大的贵族势力变得软弱无力，曾经为争夺法王宝座而互相争斗的贵族现在发现他们只能通过讨好路易十四而获得特权。[PARAGRAPH:2]即使如此，凡尔赛宫也显得太过奢华。据估计，仅仅是维持凡尔赛宫及宫廷的正常运转就需要耗费法国国家预算的百分之六。与之相比，2006年度美国国家预算总额为2.2万亿美圆，百分之六就意味着1320亿美元。[PARAGRAPH:2]法国大革命以后，君主制土崩瓦解，凡尔赛宫则被废弃不用。德国人在1870年普法战争中击败法国后将此处作为陆军司令部。这一建筑直到20世纪60年代一直处于荒废状态，直到皮埃尔·维尔莱提出了翻修凡尔赛宫，让它重新焕发路易十四时代荣光的大胆设想。直到今日，凡尔赛博物馆已经从欧洲各地找回了原本保存于凡尔赛宫的大量馆藏品。

TEXT.English: Before the establishment of centralized governments capable of supporting strong, national armies, individual cities were left to fend for themselves when it came to defense. As a result, many cities constructed city walls to protect against raiders and bandits. City walls represented a major investment in both time and materials, requiring years to complete and constant repairs to maintain their strength and integrity. However, these walls turned the city into a fortress capable of withstanding all but the most determined attack. The development of gunpowder largely put an end to the usefulness of walls in stopping large armies.
TEXT.Chinese: 在有能力维持强大国家军队的中央集权政府建立起来之前，地方城市往往需要自行组织防御力量。因此，许多城市都会修建城墙阻止入侵者以及盗贼的攻击。修建城墙意味着大量的时间与金钱投入，在花费数年时间建造完成之后，仍需时时维护以确保其坚固完好。不过，城墙的确能使城市变成一座军事要塞，让大量来犯之敌无功而返。在火药发明之后，城墙基本失去了阻止敌军进攻的作用。

TEXT.English: Castles served many functions in medieval Europe; not only were they formidable defensive positions, but they served as administrative and judicial centers and as the seat of a lord's power. Since food and supplies could be stockpiled at castles, they exerted strong influence over very large surrounding territories. Secular lords were not the only ones to build castles; religious officials often did so as well, to provide themselves with stronger power bases. Early castles were usually little more than wooden stockades constructed on dirt mounds and perhaps surrounded by a shallow trench; by the time of the reign of Edward the Confessor in 13th century England, castle-building had become a much more elaborate affair, with hundreds of laborers and specialists constructing huge stone fortresses with intricate defenses in carefully selected geographic locations. After gunpowder brought cannons into widespread use, castles failed to provide the same protection from attack, and later rulers built palaces more along aesthetic than defensive lines.
TEXT.Chinese: 城堡在中世纪的欧洲有许多作用；并不仅仅是作为一个强大的防御工事而存在，它们同时还是行政和司法的中心，以及领主权力的象征。因为事物和其它补给可以大量存放在城堡内，其影响力就可以覆盖附近的广大地区。并不是只有领主才会建造城堡；教会的高层也常常这样做，这是为了有一个强大的权力基础。早期的城堡不过是建造在土堆上的木制围墙，或许还会有浅壕沟环绕于外；直到13世纪的英格兰国王忏悔者爱德华统治时期，建造城堡才成了一项精细的工程，需要有数以百计的工人和专家，在精心选择的地点建造高大的石制要塞和复杂的防御工事。但在火药的广泛使用之后，城堡已无法对抗攻击武器，所以此后建造的城堡注重美学价值更甚于注重防御用途。

TEXT.English: Warfare has been a recurring phenomenon throughout the history of mankind, and it continues to plague the world today. Although war is not a desirable situation, it is important that even the most peaceful of societies be prepared for the possibility of war. When warring nations are closely matched in technology and manpower, the army with the best training usually wins battles.Military schools and academies exist all over the world, established for the purpose of training military personnel in the latest methods, tactics, and technology. Men and women who graduate from such facilities possess higher than average command and military and technological skills, making them more effective in combat situations.
TEXT.Chinese: 战争是人类历史上频繁出现的现象，直到今天仍给人类制造着灾难。尽管战争并非人们所愿，但即便是最和平的社会也要随时防备着它的来临。当交战国在科技和人力方面相匹敌时，更训练有素的军队通常能赢得战斗。军事院校今天已遍布世界，其建立的目的是为了用最新的方法，战术，科技培训军事人员。军事学院的毕业生拥有更高水准的指挥，军事和科技技能，从而使他们在战场环境中的能力更强。

TEXT.English: The term "bunker" is often used to denote military bomb shelters, often those housing high officials of the military and government. As shown in the second United States-Iraq War, a country with air dominance over a foe can do significant amounts of damage to a city with just a few bombs. Military and political leaders are prime targets for such attacks; often these officials will be protected in bunkers far below city streets. Bunkers are also used to protect communications networks, another important target. [PARAGRAPH:1]Any improvement in defense usually sparks an improvement in offensive weapons. The United States is building special "bunker-buster" bombs, designed to burrow deep into the ground before exploding. While such bombs may not destroy the deepest bunkers, they can cut off their communications, escape routes and air supply.
TEXT.Chinese: 地堡通常表示军用防弹掩体，它们是为军方和政府的高层服务的。就像第二次美国——伊拉克战争中表现出的那样，拥有绝对制空权的一方可以用少量炸弹造成敌人的严重损失。而军方和政府首脑通常是空中打击的首要目标；所以这些官员必须在城市地表下接受地堡的保护。地堡还要用来保护另一个重要目标——通信网络。[PARAGRAPH:1]但任何防御上的提高必然面临攻击武器性能的提升。美国已经开发出了“地堡终结者”，它可以在穿透地层到达目标后才爆炸。但即使是这种炸弹也无法摧毁那些深入地下的掩体，只能通过切断其通信，迂回进路及空气来源而使它们失去作用。

TEXT.English: A bomb shelter is a structure designed to protect the people inside from falling bombs. Today's bomb shelters are designed to shield one from the destruction of a nuclear attack. People have constructed bomb shelters since the first artillery piece was put into action. Sometimes these are rude caves dug in a hillside; sometimes they are elaborate and complicated affairs, self-sustaining for weeks, dug hundreds of feet below the surface.[PARAGRAPH:1]In the 1950s during the Cold War, American citizens began constructing bomb shelters in their back yards and basements, hoping to avoid destruction during the atomic war they were sure was coming. The US government embarked on an ambitious program to create large bomb shelters in all major cities, stocking them with food, water, blankets, and other essential supplies. These are mostly abandoned today, probably because of the realization that most of them are not strong enough to do much good in the event of a nuclear attack.
TEXT.Chinese: 防空洞原本是为了让人们躲避炸弹而建造的。现代防空洞的设计意图则是为了防御核打击。自从炮兵出现后，人类就开始建造此类设施。有些防空洞只是简单地在山腹挖个洞；有些则是精心建造的复杂工事，位于地下数百米处，可以在失去同外界联系的情况支持许多个星期。[PARAGRAPH:1]在20世纪50年代的冷战时期，美国人纷纷在自家后院建造防空洞，希望藉此在看上去必将来临的核子战争中存活下来。美国政府则把注意力放到在各个主要城市建造巨型防空洞上，并在里面堆放大量食物、饮用水、毯子以及其它必需的物资。这些防空洞现在几乎都被废弃了，这可能是因为人们意识到它们并不足以防御核打击。

TEXT.English: Early humans were nomadic, settling in specific regions only for brief periods of time. When the food supply was exhausted in one area, the nomads would move on to search for more. Cities became possible only when the development of agriculture made the supply of food more abundant and dependable. However, cities still needed a way to keep the food supply stable throughout all four seasons. To do so, the citizens had to come up with a way to store seasonal crops for later use. The Granary was designed for the storage and protection of surplus food. Food storage technology meant that a smaller percentage of the population could produce and store enough food for everyone, allowing the remainder to pursue other jobs and activities.
TEXT.Chinese: 早期人类过着游牧生活，只在特定的地方作短期居留。当一个地方的食物用尽之后，这些游牧民族就会继续寻找新的地方。城市的形成是在发明农耕而粮食供给变得更加丰富可靠之后。然而，城市仍然需要一个四季都可以稳定提供粮食的方法。为此，人们想出一个办法，可以贮存这些季节性的作物，供日后食用。粮仓就是设计用来贮存粮食的设施。粮食贮存技术意味着只需较少的人口就可以生产并贮存足够的粮食，而让其他人从事别的工作和活动。

TEXT.English: A major obstacle to population growth and expansion in early cities was the scarcity of water. In many cases, the solution to this problem was an aqueduct. Aqueducts were large, elevated stone "canals" through which water from nearby hills and mountains was channeled into the city. Aqueducts allowed cities to grow much larger by significantly increasing the amount of available water. At the same time aqueducts reduced the chance of contracting water-borne diseases, by reducing the dependence on stagnant ponds and wells as water sources. Aqueducts also allowed cities to be built in normally inhospitable environments, such as deserts, by providing an outside water source. Modern day Los Angeles, for example, obtains its water supply from the Colorado River, through a system of aqueducts over 200 miles long.
TEXT.Chinese: 限制早期城市人口增长的主要问题是水的缺乏。在多数情况下，人们修筑水渠以解决这一问题。水渠是石筑的大型高架沟槽，附近高山与丘陵中的水由此被引导至城市之中。由于引水渠给城市提供了大量的水，人口数量和城市的大扩展成为可能。同时水渠的应用使得人们对蓄水池和井的依赖性降低从而减少了感染水传播疾病的几率。通过从外地引来水源，水渠也使得人们可以在以往被认为不适宜居住的地方，例如沙漠之中，建立城市。现代的洛杉矶，它的城市用水就是通过一个引水渠道系统从200英里之外的科罗拉多河取得的。

TEXT.English: Hospitals are institutions that focus on the diagnosis and treatment of disease and trauma. While dispensing these services, they also provide housing. With technological innovation in medicine, hospitals have increasingly become community hubs, expanding their role to include teaching and research. Throughout history a hospital's role has shifted from a place to secure the ill or insane, to one of hope and health.
TEXT.Chinese: 医院是诊断，治疗疾病及创伤的机构，除此之外，还提供住院服务。在医疗改革之后，医院也开始更重要的角色，它变成了社会进行医学教学以及研究的中心。而医院的角色也从历史上提供病人安养的地方变成了希望及健康的象征。

TEXT.English: The continual growth in city populations leads to an inevitable increase in garbage. Eventually, existing landfills and garbage dumps are filled, forcing new dumping sites to be established. This leads to the gradual but steady destruction of the local environment. To reverse this problem, many areas have established recycling centers, where much of the garbage is sorted and reduced to reusable components through various means. These components are then used to manufacture new products. In this way, much of the trash produced is turned into raw materials for production, rather than contributing to the ever-increasing pollution problem.
TEXT.Chinese: 城市人口的不断增长必然导致废弃物的增加。终于，现有的垃圾填埋场和堆放点都塞满了垃圾，人们不得不建立新的填埋地。这将逐渐对当地环境造成难以消除的破坏。为了解决这个问题，许多地方建立了回收中心。人们在那里将垃圾分类并通过很多方法将其变为可重复利用的资源。这些资源将被用来制造新的产品。由此，大量的废弃物被转换成工业生产的原料，而不是造成更多的污染问题。

TEXT.English: A lighthouse is a tower constructed on the shoreline, usually near a harbor or busy waterway. A powerful light sits atop the tower, making the structure visible to mariners for miles around. Lighthouses are built to mark the location of rocks and shoals or other hazards in the dead of night or midst of storms. Before the invention of radar, electricity, and global positioning systems, any vessel sailing near the shore ran a risk of running into such hazards and sinking. Naturally, sailors preferred to sail to destinations that had a method of marking these perils, so harbors with lighthouses flourished. [PARAGRAPH:1]The original "lighthouse" was probably a bonfire lit by villagers to guide the village's fishing vessels back to harbor at night. Over time people realized that the fires could be seen much farther away if they were built atop platforms or towers. Further improvements were made as technology advanced; mirrors were built to direct the light in the desired directions; oil lamps replaced the more dangerous bonfires, which were in turn replaced by electric lamps.
TEXT.Chinese: 灯塔是建造在海岸线上的一座塔，一般位于毗邻海港或者繁忙的航线上。塔顶发出醒目的光，使数十英里范围内的船员都可以看到。建造灯塔是为了在漆黑的夜里或者暴风雨中标示暗礁，浅滩或其他危险的地方。在雷达，电和全球定位系统发明以前，近海航行的船只都要冒着沉没或搁浅的巨大风险。自然的，海员更倾向于航行在那些标记了危险地段的线路上，因此，建有灯塔的海港变得繁荣起来。[PARAGRAPH:1]最初的灯塔大概就是村民们为了引导晚归渔船安全回港燃起的篝火。时光流逝，人们认识到如果把火放在平台或者塔的顶上，那么很远都可以看得见。随着技术的进步，灯塔逐步升级换代；镜子被用来把光引导到预期的方向；油灯取代了危险的篝火，后来又被电灯取代。

TEXT.English: Just because a city is built in a coastal region doesn't guarantee that the city is readily accessible by ship. In order for a port city to establish a steady trade, fishing, or other shipping industry, the city must have a harbor. A harbor is a protected body of water that opens into an ocean or lake that shelters ships from waves and high winds. Although some coastal cities are established in areas where a natural harbor exists, most seaports are forced either to improve the existing natural harbor, or to build a man-made harbor to shelter ships and provide channels deep enough to accommodate large vessels.
TEXT.Chinese: 城市座落在海岸边并不表示这个城市可以让船只停靠。一个城市想要建立稳定的海上贸易，捕鱼业和其他航运业，就必须拥有一个港口。港口可以为海洋或湖泊上的船只躲避大风巨浪时提供保护。虽然一些沿海城市拥有天然的港湾，但是大多数这样的天然海港仍需要进行改善或者建筑人工港口以收容船只并挖掘能通行大型船舶的深水航道。

TEXT.English: A drydock is a facility for constructing and repairing ships. Drydocks may be floating structures or land-based. They contain one or more large bays in which the ship-work is done. These bays are below sea-level and contain drainage systems and water-tight doors. While construction or repairs are going on, the drydock is dry, the vessel sitting on the dock's floor supported by an elaborate structure of scaffolding. When construction or repairs are complete, the dock is flooded and the ship floats gently off the scaffolding. Once the water level inside the dock reaches sea-level, the drydock's doors are opened and the ship can proceed to sea.
TEXT.Chinese: 干船坞是用于船只建造和修理的设施。干船坞分为浮船坞和固定船坞。它包含一个或多个用于船只作业的大型汊港。这些汊港底部低于海平面，并装有排水系统和防水闸门。当建造或修理工作进行时，船坞是干的，船停放在船坞板上并由精心制作的脚手架支撑。当建造或者修理工作结束时，船坞注水使船浮起渐渐离开脚手架。一旦船坞里的水达到了水平面的高度，船坞的防水闸门就会打开让里面的船驶向大海。

TEXT.English: Since the middle of the 20th century, the airplane has been one of the chief means of long-distance transport in the world. Nearly every major metropolitan area today has at least one airport, with facilities to handle passengers and ticketing, as well as facilities for refueling and repairing the aircraft that land there. Beginning in the 1940s, the growing role of airplanes as combat vehicles led to the widespread construction of military air bases. Nearly 400 of these facilities in the U.S. alone act as bases and maintenance facilities for aircraft assigned to all branches of the military.
TEXT.Chinese: 在二十世纪中期，飞机已经成为世界上主要的长途运输工具之一。而现在，几乎每个大都会都有至少一座机场，它们即能为旅客提供客运和票务服务，又能为着陆的飞机提供加油及维修服务。在20世纪40年代初期，越来越多的飞机被用作战斗，这造成了大量空军基地的出现。现在美国境内有多达400座的军用机场做为基地，并为部署在各军事部门的飞机提供维护服务。

TEXT.English: A forge is a furnace where metal is heated or melted. In ancient times smiths with small forges could be found in most settlements. The furnaces were stoked with coal, which was fanned by manually pumped bellows to create intense heat. The blacksmith would heat the metal in the oven and then shape it by putting the metal on an anvil and beating it with heavy hammers. The finished product was then put into cold water to harden and cool. The smith might also melt the metal and pour it into molds. [PARAGRAPH:1]Modern forges are huge industrial structures requiring many workers to operate. The operation is similar to that in the smithy; except on a grand scale. Tons of ore are poured into massive vats, which are conveyed into the furnace. Once the metal is smelted, it may be mixed with other materials to create an alloy such as steel, and it may undergo a number of different processes to remove impurities. The finished metal can then be rolled into sheets, poured into molds, stamped into coins, and so forth.
TEXT.Chinese: 煅造场的熔炉是一个能让金属加热熔化的炉子。在远古时代所有的定居点都能找到自带小熔炉的铁匠。炉子里面放着碳，在用人力风箱吹进去的风作用下，发出大量热能。铁匠在炉子里加热金属，再把它放到铁砧上通过用重锤不停的敲击来塑形。接着，成品被放进冷水中冷却成形。铁匠也可以熔化金属然后把它灌注到模子中。[PARAGRAPH:1]现代熔炉是一个大型的工业建筑需要很多工人来操作。其实，操作流程和古代的铁匠铺里的操作相似，只是规模巨大而已。数以吨计的矿石被倾泻到结实的桶中，搬进熔炉里。一旦金属被冶炼，往冶炼过的金属中加入其他的材料就生成了合金，例如钢，它可能会经历数种不同的处理来去除杂质。完成的金属被轧成一片片的，被灌注到模子里，被压印成硬币和其它的用途。

TEXT.English: Early examples of factory-like production, where a number of individuals work cooperatively to produce goods for sale or trade, can be found as far back as ancient Greece and Rome. Modern factories, however, evolved from the concept of specialized labor, where each worker performed a single step in the overall production of an item. This specialization allows factories to increase the speed and efficiency of the manufacturing process, far surpassing earlier means of production. The development of the factory system as a means of production played a key role in the Industrial Revolution.
TEXT.Chinese: 工厂的雏型可追溯到古希腊及古罗马时期。当时的工厂只是一群个体相互合作去生产用于销售或交易的物品。而现代的工厂则是从专有分工这一概念发展而来，每个工人只负责整个生产流程中的一个步骤。这些专有分工提高了工厂的生产效率，大大超过了以前的合作生产方式。在工业革命时期，工厂系统作为一种生产方式不断地发展，并扮演着一个很重要的角色。

TEXT.English: Coal has been used sporadically as a fuel since ancient times, but it was not until the Industrial Revolution that the industrial applications of coal became understood. Most early factories used coal as a power supply, burning the fossil fuel to release the energy needed to drive the plant's machines. Coal power provided much more energy than relying on the strength of humans or animals, at the cost of releasing large amounts of toxic pollution into the atmosphere. Despite the environmental hazards associated with coal plants, they remain common today.
TEXT.Chinese: 煤很早就被用作燃料，到工业革命时期，煤在工业上开始广泛应用。大部分的早期工厂使用煤作为能源，燃烧这种古老的燃料来释放能量，驱动工厂里的机器。火力相比人力和畜力，能提供多得多的能量，但其代价就是释放大量的有毒的污染物进入大气层。尽管它们的存在对周围环境带来危害，但是火电站在今天仍然十分普遍。

TEXT.English: One alternative to power generation utilizing coal or petroleum fuels is the hydroelectric power plant. This facility utilizes the energy of rapidly moving water to turn the turbines of its generators and produce electricity. In locations where a source of moving water is available, hydro plants offer a clean, safe alternative to coal, petroleum, and nuclear power generation. Hydro plants have their own set of environmental dangers, however. The disruption of a river's normal flow and the massive flooding of the land behind the facility's dam can destroy the habitat of the wildlife inhabiting the river basin.
TEXT.Chinese: 替代使用煤及石油来发电的另外一种方案就是水力发电站。它的原理是靠快速流动的水流来推动涡轮并产生电力。在一个适合水力发电的地点上建立水电站，它就可以提供比燃煤、石油和核能更干净，安全的电力来源。水电站当然也会造成环境破坏，那就是利用水坝来阻断河流的正常流动会破坏流域上的野生动物的栖息地。

TEXT.English: Nuclear power plants utilize radioactive materials and the process of nuclear fission to generate the heat and steam needed to run electrical generators and produce electricity. Because nuclear power doesn't cause the air pollution associated with the burning of coal or petroleum products, this means of generating power is considered a viable alternative energy source. However, the toxic nature of the byproducts produced by the fission process creates serious problems of its own. No method of safely disposing of this toxic waste has been found, and the volatile nature of the fission reaction can lead to a meltdown of the reactor core if the reaction is not properly controlled. Because of these problems, the future of nuclear power is uncertain.
TEXT.Chinese: 核电站利用放射性材料和核裂变方法产生热量和蒸汽，驱动发电机发电。由于核能不会导致煤或油燃烧所产生的空气污染，因为它被视为一种可选择的替代能源。然而，核裂变所产生的放射性副产品产生了很严重的问题。目前还没有发现安全处理这些有毒废料的方法，而且裂变反应有不稳定性，如果控制不当，会导致核反应堆熔毁。正是由于这些问题，使得核能的未来尚难确定。

TEXT.English: An obelisk is a structure that reminds people of an important event that occured in the area, or an important person who lived, such as famous generals of rememberances of a particulary bloody conflict.
TEXT.Chinese: 方尖碑是用来记录当地发生过的重要事件，或者生活过的重要人物的建筑物，例如记念指挥某场战役的著名将领。

TEXT.English: An academy is a school for advanced learning. Though China, Egypt, and India had such institutes earlier, the term "academy" was first applied to the Athenian school of philosophy, founded by Plato in approximately 390 BC. The school was built near a sacred grove named "Hekademia." [PARAGRAPH:1]An academy was an important asset for a city. It attracted both brilliant scholars and the children of wealthy or noble parents, who might then decide to settle in the city permanently. The academy could provide a broad, general education to its students, or it might concentrate upon a specific subject such as philosophy, mathematics, art, natural philosophy (the world and everything in it), or the martial arts. [PARAGRAPH:1]Today there are many educational facilities which bear the name "academy." The term is used loosely now, and in addition to its original meaning, is often applied to schools for children and teenagers.
TEXT.Chinese: 科学院是一个从事深入学术研究的机构。虽然中国，埃及和印度很早就有这样的机构，但是科学院（“阿卡德美”）一词最早是指柏拉图于公元前390年建立于雅典的哲学学园。这个学园坐落在一处名叫“赫卡德米亚”的神圣小树林附近。[PARAGRAPH:1]科学院是一个城市的重要资产。他既吸引有才华的学者，又招徕来自贵族或富人家庭的子女，而他们则可能在此后一直定居于这座城市。科学院可以为求学者提供内容广博的教育，也可以专注于某项特定的科目，例如哲学，数学，艺术，自然科学（世界及世间万物的科学）或者武术。[PARAGRAPH:1]现在很多教育机构都举着“科学院”的旗号。现在这个术语的使用宽松了，除了原始的意思，它还经常被用于进行儿童和青少年教育的学校。

TEXT.English: The development of writing meant that the accumulated knowledge of a society could be written down and stored rather than memorized and passed along by word of mouth. The accumulated written material was stored in a library. The libraries of the ancient world, especially those at Alexandria and Pergamum, became leading centers of science and scholarship. The librarians actively collected the books of the world, accelerating the spread of knowledge.
TEXT.Chinese: 文字的发明使前人积累的知识可以通过文字留存下来，而不是以口头讲述以及记忆的方式来传递这些知识。这些累积的知识可以被存放在一座图书馆之中。图书馆在古代，特别是在亚历山大及帕加马，成为了科学以及哲学的领导核心。图书馆主动地收集世界上的书籍，加速了知识的传播。

TEXT.English: Universities are institutions of higher learning. Early universities, established in the Middle Ages, were usually built in cities that had a large or important cathedral. Studies at these institutions focused on matters concerning the church. The curricula quickly expanded to include classical art, literature, and languages. Modern universities provide the opportunity to study a wide array of subjects. They have also become centers for research into many fields, serving as the source of major advances in computers, medicine, physics, and a variety of other subjects.
TEXT.Chinese: 大学是高等教育机构。建立于中古时期的大学通常建造在有大型或重要教堂的城市之中，而这些大学的学习重点也着重于教会的事物上。不过后来很快地就扩展到古典艺术，文学以及语言之上。现代的大学则提供了相当广泛的学习机会，同时也培育了很多新学科，例如电子计算机、医学、物理等。

TEXT.English: An observatory is a building designed to allow those inside to study the stars, usually with the aid of a telescope. Early observatories consisted of buildings with conveniently-placed windows or high platforms, while later models have sophisticated rotating roofs with an aperture to hold a massive telescope. The rooftop rotates to allow the telescope to point in any direction. [PARAGRAPH:1]An observatory's location has much to do with its efficacy. Smog and other pollutants cut down on visibility; further, stars become more difficult to observe when there are other light-sources visible; so modern observatories are usually built as far away from cities as practical.
TEXT.Chinese: 天文台是一种通常放置着望远镜，供人们研究星辰的建筑物。早期的天文台由一些方便开启的窗户或者高台组成，近代的样式则装有可旋转的屋顶，并有一个洞口可以放置巨大的望远镜。旋转屋顶可以使望远镜朝向任何一个方向。[PARAGRAPH:1]天文台的位置极大地影响着望远镜观测的效果。烟尘和其他污染物会遮挡住可见光；而且，如果附近有其他的可见光源，星星将更加难以观测；所以现代天文台经常建在尽可能远离城市的地方。

TEXT.English: Historically, libraries and universities have acted as the primary centers of research for new ideas and technologies. The growth of private industry in the Modern Age has also given birth to hundreds of privately owned research facilities. These private laboratories, usually dedicated to research in a single field related to their founding company, have made tremendous advances in many fields including physics, biology, chemistry, and medicine. The growth of privately-funded research has vastly increased the speed at which mankind achieves new advances in science and technology.
TEXT.Chinese: 历史上，图书馆和大学是研究新思想和新科技的重要中心。现代私营企业的成长也催生了成千上百的私人研究机构。这些私人实验室通常致力研究与他们创建的公司有关的单一领域，并在物理学、生物学、化学、医学等诸多领域取得了巨大进步。这些私人资助的研究大大推动了人类的科技进步。

TEXT.English: A theatre is a building in which audiences can watch a play or other theatrical performance. The earliest theatres were outdoors, constructed in a bowl-shaped depression to allow all in the audience to see the stage. Later, specific buildings were constructed to house theatres.[PARAGRAPH:1] Modern theatres are similar in layout to the earliest buildings. The audience sits or stands facing a stage; behind the stage is an extensive backstage area holding sets, props, dressing rooms and so forth. The primary difference between stages of Shakespeare's time and modern theaters is that the latter have electrical systems allowing them to light the stage as needed and to amplify the actors' voices.
TEXT.Chinese: 剧场是一种供观众在欣赏歌剧或者其他戏剧节目的建筑场所。最古老的剧场是露天的，被设计成逐渐下凹的碗状，这样所有观众们都可以看到舞台。后来，剧场被设计成室内建筑。[PARAGRAPH:1]现代剧场在形式上保留了一些古典建筑的特色。观众或坐或站的面对着舞台；在舞台之后是一个大型的后台区域，包括舞台布景、道具、化妆间及其他设施。现今的剧场相比莎士比亚时期的剧场，主要的差别是增加了一系列电子设备，在需要的时候可以给舞台照明或者放大演员的声音。

TEXT.English: The original colosseum provided entertainment for the common people of Roman society by presenting them with spectacles and events as a temporary escape from day-to-day life. This concept has been revived in the 20th Century. Modern-day stadiums and civic centers provide an arena for entertainment ranging from concerts to professional sporting events. Although the violent spectacle of gladiatorial combat is a thing of the past, today's colosseums still provide entertainment and diversion for the masses.
TEXT.Chinese: 最初，竞技场的作用是取悦罗马公民，日复一日平淡生活的他们可以从中获得解脱。这个概念在二十世纪又开始流行了。现代的体育场和市中心也提供娱乐场所，包括音乐会和职业体育赛事。虽然血腥刺激的角斗活动是古老时代的产物，不过今天的竞技场仍旧提供了人民大众喜闻乐见的娱乐及消遣。

TEXT.English: Although newspapers are published on a daily basis, they cannot often keep up to date on what is happening at the moment. Radio provides a means of doing that, as well as providing entertainment sources that would not otherwise be possible. With many events that occur in the world, it is important that the goverment be able to repudiate claims made by others, especially those that are true! Although radio has been superceeded by the television in most parts of the world, it is still a valuable tool to disseminate pro-goverment propaganda to the populace.
TEXT.Chinese: 即使报纸现在以日报的形式出版，仍然有很多消息不能及时登报。无线电广播就可以做到这一点，同时它也可以传播其他途径无法传送的信息资源。每时每刻，在这个世界上都会发生很多事件，对政府来说，驳斥他人的言论是非常重要的，尤其是那言论本身是正确的时候！尽管无线电广播在世界上很多地方已经被电视所取代，它仍然是政府用来向民众传播思想的有用的工具。

TEXT.English: As cities grew and prospered, trade between the farmers, artisans, and craftsmen who lived in the vicinity contributed to the economic health of the city. It soon became apparent that the best way for conducting trade within the city was to have a central location, or marketplace, where the people offering goods and services, or seeking them, could meet and conduct business. As a city's marketplace grew larger and more active, the economic vitality of the city grew as well.
TEXT.Chinese: 当城市成长并繁荣起来，住在城市邻近区域的农夫、工匠、技工们就会开始互相交易，同时对城市的经济做出贡献。显而易见，在市中心有个固定场所，比如市场，是最好的贸易方式，人们可以在这里出售货物或提供服务，也方面他们寻觅货物或接洽生意。当一个城市的市场变得庞大而且更加活跃，城市的经济活力也相应增长起来。

TEXT.English: The word "grocer" is the ancient term for a grocery store. It denotes a market, usually under single ownership (unlike the older bazaar-style markets, which contain dozens or hundreds of small independent operations). The store sells fresh foodstuffs as well as canned goods and other household staples. [PARAGRAPH:1]Modern groceries - also known as "supermarkets" - are much larger than the originals, thanks in large part to the invention of refrigeration. They contain an extensive variety of foods from all over the world. Comparatively, food prices are much lower than they used to be, and today's families spend a historically low portion of their income on food of much higher variety than that offered to shoppers in the past.
TEXT.Chinese: “杂货店”是综合店铺的旧式称谓。它代表着一类市场，通常由一位业主管理（不像古代中东的街市那样有很多个体小商贩组成）。杂货店里贮存并销售多种新鲜的食品、罐头食品和其他日常用品。[PARAGRAPH:1]现代杂货店——就是我们熟知的“超级市场”——比传统的店铺更大，这要归功于冷藏技术的发明。这里保存着来自世界各个地方的多种多样的食物。同时这里的食物价格相比小店铺要便宜不少，今天的家庭花在食物上的支出要比过去少得多，而购买的选择却多得多。

TEXT.English: A highly developed banking system is one of the cornerstones of an advanced civilization. Banks lend money to individuals or groups, providing capital for industrial and real estate development. Banks also contribute to the economic growth of a city or region by stimulating the development of production facilities. Individual citizens can also benefit by investing their own surplus money in the bank and earning interest on it.
TEXT.Chinese: 拥有一个高度发达的银行融体系是成为一个先进国家的基石。银行可以贷款给个人或是集体，也可以向工业及不动产业的发展提供资本。通过刺激工业产品生产，银行还促进了城市的经济发展。而市民个人也可以把他们多余的钱存在银行来赚取利息。

TEXT.English: Supermarkets are large, self-service retail stores that sell a wide variety of food items and household goods to the general public. The first true supermarket, King Kullen, was established in 1930 in the borough of Queens, New York City, by Michael Cullen. Improved storage techniques and refrigeration allowed supermarkets to stock and sell perishable foods in large quantities, reducing the price to the consumer. The combination of ready availability and low prices made the supermarket an instant success in the U.S. during the years of the Great Depression. The supermarket continues to grow in popularity in countries around the world.
TEXT.Chinese: 超级市场是大型的自选零售商场，向人们出售各种各样的食物和日常用品。第一家真正的超级市场是1930年在纽约市皇后区成立的金顾伦商场，创始人为麦克尔·顾伦。储存技术和冷藏技术的发展使超级市场可以大批量的供应新鲜食品，并降低商品的价格。选择多样和价格便宜使超级市场即使在美国大萧条时期仍然迅速获得成功。目前，超级市场正在世界范围内普及开来。

TEXT.English: As kingdoms and empires expanded, it became increasingly difficult for the rulers to maintain control over the more distant regions of their realm. To ensure that the far-flung cities of the empire contributed their expected share of duties and taxes to the government, rulers constructed courthouses to help unify their domains. These local centers of government meted out justice and helped preserve order in the midst of the furthest wilderness.
TEXT.Chinese: 当国家领土大大扩张之后，统治者控制疆域内每个遥远地区的难度日益增加。为了确保偏远的城市也能对政府的赋税有所贡献，地方法庭开始设立起来。这些地方分支统治机构负责伸张正义，保证边远地区的正常社会秩序。

TEXT.English: A jail is a building for holding prisoners. Jails can range in size from a single room to a sprawling complex of buildings inside miles of barbed wire. Prisoners incarcerated in a jail may be there for a variety of reasons. Some may be common criminals; others may be brutal murderers. Some may be captured enemy soldiers and spies. Some might be political prisoners, dissidents, or simply people who fell into bad grace with their rulers. Some might be mad - incarceration being a common way to deal with the insane before the creation of mental hospitals and sanitariums. [PARAGRAPH:1] The facilities inside jails vary widely. A jail for commoners or enemies of the state might be horrible, overcrowded dark pits that are infested with rats, while a king's prison may be indistinguishable from royal quarters, except for the small matter of which side of the door on which the guards stand. Mostly, jails are unpleasant and unhappy places.
TEXT.Chinese: 监狱是用来关押犯人的建筑物，通常由数公里的铁丝网围成的区域内放置若干排单人房间构成。犯人可能因为很多原因被关进监狱。有些可能是普通的罪犯；而另一些可能就是杀人犯。有些可能是敌国被俘虏的士兵和间谍。有些则可能是政治犯，持不同政见者，或者是普通的被统治者迫害的老百姓。有些则是精神病患者——在专门的精神病院和疗养院建立之前，精神病人通常也是在那里关押的。[PARAGRAPH:1]监狱的用途很广泛。关押平民或者国家敌人的监狱是相当可怕的，在那里，狭小地窖的昏暗角落里遍布老鼠。不过除了卫兵在门外还是门内站岗位置的差别之外，关押国王的监狱和往往和普通的王宫并无差别。总之，监狱是一个令人痛苦和不舒服的地方。

TEXT.English: According to Jewish tradition, Solomon's Temple was the first Jewish temple in Jerusalem, and, as the "dwelling place of God," the single most important building in the Jewish religion. Construction was begun by King David and completed by his son, Solomon. The temple was built by Phoenician workers using the finest materials available - stones quarried from beneath the city, wood from Lebanon, and 3000 tons of gold and 30,000 tons of silver. The result was an astonishingly beautiful edifice standing some 30 yards long by 10 yards wide by 16 yards in height. It took seven years to complete the Temple.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Temple consisted of three main rooms surrounded by smaller chambers. Upon climbing a set of stairs, the visitor would enter the vestibule, which was topped with two enormous pillars given the names of Jachin and Boaz. From there the visitor would proceed into the "Greater House" or "Holy Place," wherein important religious services were performed. Beyond the Greater House lay the "Holy of Holies," a square, cedar-lined room which held the "Ark of the Covenant." The Ark of the Covenant was a sacred container which held the stone tablets upon which were written the Ten Commandments, given by God to Moses. The building was surrounded by a courtyard in which the people worshipped. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Temple was pillaged many times over the years, and it was finally looted and burned to the ground by King Nebuchadnezzar II of Babylon some time around 580 BC, during the time of the "Babylonian Captivity." Years later, many of the Temple's treasures were returned to the Jews by King [LINK=LEADER_CYRUS]Cyrus[\LINK] of Persia, but the Ark was missing. Some believe that the Ark was removed and hidden before the Babylonian attack, while others believe that the Ark was captured by Babylon and then destroyed or lost. The Ethiopian Orthodox Church claims to possess the Ark, it having been brought there by one of Solomon's sons. In any case, the destruction of the Temple was total, and there is much controversy and debate about where it originally stood. [PARAGRAPH:2]The "Second Temple" was constructed in Jerusalem in approximately 500 BC. It in turn was destroyed by the Romans in 70 AD. All that remains of this building is the "Western Wall," also known as the "Wailing Wall."
TEXT.Chinese: 据犹太典籍记载，耶路撒冷的所罗门圣殿是犹太教的“第一圣殿”，作为“神的居所”，是犹太信仰中最重要的一座建筑。圣殿工程由大卫王发起，并由其子所罗门最终建成。圣殿由腓尼基工匠使用最好的材料建造——采自耶路撒冷地下的岩石，来自黎巴嫩的香柏木，3000吨黄金以及30,000吨白银等。完成的圣殿长30码，宽10码，高16码。全部工程共耗时七年完成。[PARAGRAPH:2]整个圣殿建筑群包括三个主厅及环绕四周的许多小厅。访问者需先通过长长的台阶到达殿廊，殿廊前立有由两根巨大的铜柱，名为“雅斤”和“波阿斯”。穿过殿廊即进入主殿（或称“圣所”）。献祭仪式在此处进行。在主殿之后还有“至圣所”，此处以雪松木装饰，用于放置神圣的“约柜”。当初神所赐予摩西，刻写着十戒的两块石板即保存于约柜之中。围绕圣殿的是供百姓进行祈祷的宽阔场院。[PARAGRAPH:2]所罗门圣殿在历史上曾多次遭受劫难，最终于约公元前580年被巴比伦国王尼布甲尼撒所焚毁，在持续多年的“巴比伦之囚”结束之后，波斯国王[LINK=LEADER_CYRUS]居鲁士[\LINK]将圣殿中原有的许多珍宝归还给犹太人，但是约柜却已经丢失。有人认为约柜在巴比伦军队入城之前已被转移藏匿，也有人认为是在落入巴比伦人之手后被毁或失踪。埃塞俄比亚正教会曾宣称约柜在其手中，是所罗门的后裔带往当地的。无伦如何，圣殿已彻底被毁，其具体所在位置也成了一个充满争议的问题。[PARAGRAPH:2]耶路撒冷的“第二圣殿”建于约公元前500年。在公元70年又被罗马人摧毁。存留至今的圣殿遗迹只有其西墙，即著名的“哭墙”。

TEXT.English: In Civilization IV, a temple is defined as a building where the faithful come to worship. Christians call their temples "churches," while Muslims call theirs "mosques," and Jews call theirs, simply, "temples." Temples are far more common than cathedrals, but much less large and ornate. Even the smallest village can possess a temple. [PARAGRAPH:1]Traditionally, the term "synagogue" is used to describe all Jewish houses of worship. For purposes of game clarity, Civilization IV uses the term to describe only the larger and more imposing structures; smaller religious structures are called "Jewish temples." [PARAGRAPH:1]Temples are places of prayer and study. Worshipers attend services on the "Shabbat" (or Sabbath), the day of rest which begins at sundown on Friday and ends at nightfall on Saturday. Jewish temples are often the center of Jewish life in a community, and may serve as schools, meeting places, libraries, and so forth.
TEXT.Chinese: 在文明IV中，寺庙（或礼拜堂）被定义为宗教信徒进行宗教活动的建筑。基教徒称之为“礼拜堂”，穆斯林称之为“清真寺”，犹太人则简单地称之为“会堂”，此类建筑比大教堂更为常见，但规模及华丽程度则不及后者。甚至连最小的村庄也可能会拥有一座“寺庙”。[PARAGRAPH:1]传统上，犹太教的宗教活动场所一律被称为“会堂”。但为了在游戏中进行区分，文明IV用这一称谓专指大型的犹太教建筑；较小的则称之为“犹太礼拜堂”。[PARAGRAPH:1]犹太礼拜堂是祈祷和研习经书的场所。祈祷仪式在“安息日”进行，即从星期五的日落时分直到星期六晚上。犹太礼拜堂往往是犹太人社交生活的中心，可能充当学校、会场、图书馆等功能。

TEXT.English: A monastery is a building where monks can retreat from the world and concentrate upon the divine. Usually a monastery will have strict rules of conduct to protect its unworldly members from temptation. In some monasteries, the monks are totally silent; in others no visitors are allowed inside. Monasteries usually have many daily rituals and religious services. [PARAGRAPH:1] Throughout the ages monasteries have often been centers of learning. In remote areas the monks may be the only literate people for miles around. Monks have often been employed as scribes, copying out the words of their religion's sacred scripture. Monasteries frequently have extensive libraries, holding religious, scientific, medical and philosophical texts. [PARAGRAPH:1]Though Judaism does not possess monasteries in the traditional sense, it does have Talmudic Academies, centers of learning where Rabbis discuss and debate the "Talmud," a record of rabbinical writings on Jewish law, ethics and custom. Aside from the Bible, the Talmud is the sole authority on many aspects of Jewish life and religious practice. Based upon earlier Jewish oral tradition, the Talmud was first put to paper in the second century, AD. It has been added to, debated and studied ever since.
TEXT.Chinese: 修道院是那些希望远离尘世，追求圣洁生活的宗教僧侣们的静修场所。通常修道院都规定有严格的行为准则，确保修道者免受外来的骚扰和诱惑。有的修道院要求人人保持静默；有的完全禁止访问者入内。僧侣们每日都须在修道院中举行宗教仪式。[PARAGRAPH:1]在古代，修道院往往也成为学术研究的中心。在边远地区，僧侣可能是当地仅有的有文化者。僧侣们经常担任抄写工作，负责传抄本宗教的经书文献。修道院通常会附有图书馆，用于存放神学、科学、医学和哲学书籍。[PARAGRAPH:1]虽然严格来说，犹太教并无传统意义上的修道院，但也建有“塔木德学院”作为其学术中心，犹太教的拉比（学者）们在其中讨论“塔木德经”（犹太法典），道德与传统规范等。除了圣经，塔木德经是犹太人生活和信仰各方面最重要的行为规范。根据记载，塔木德经的最初文本完成于公元二世纪。并在此后不断得到探讨和完善。

TEXT.English: In Civilization IV, a cathedral is defined as an especially large and ornate religious building where the faithful worship. Only the most prosperous cities can afford to create cathedrals, as they require huge amounts of raw material and years of dedicated labor by skilled craftsmen. For example, the Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris, France, took over two centuries to complete. [PARAGRAPH:1]Traditionally, the term "synagogue" is used to describe all Jewish houses of worship. For purposes of game clarity, Civilization IV uses the term to describe only the larger and more imposing structures; smaller religious structures are called "Jewish temples." [PARAGRAPH:1]A Jewish synagogue is a place both of worship and of study. Worship and prayer take place in the main room. The prayer may be led by a "rabbi" (teacher), but it is not necessary, and many synagogues do not have a rabbi in attendance. Many of the most beautiful synagogues in the world are found in Eastern Europe. Unfortunately, many of the local worshipers were killed during the Holocaust, and most survivors fled to Israel, leaving these holy buildings sadly unattended.
TEXT.Chinese: 在文明IV中，大教堂是指规模巨大，装饰华丽的宗教性建筑。只有非常繁荣的城市才有能力建造大教堂，因为此类建筑需要消耗大量原材料，并需要大批技艺精湛的工匠经年累月的努力。例如法国巴黎的圣母大教堂（巴黎圣母院）花费了两个世纪的时间才建造完成。[PARAGRAPH:1]传统上，犹太教的宗教活动场所一律被称为“会堂”。但为了在游戏中进行区分，文明IV用这一称谓专指大型的犹太教建筑；较小的则称之为“犹太礼拜堂”。[PARAGRAPH:1]犹太教会堂即是祈祷场所，也从事犹太典籍的研究。祈祷活动在会堂大厅举行。可能由一位“拉比”（犹太教学者）主持，但这并非必需，许多会堂并没有常驻的拉比。世界上最华美的犹太教会堂集中于东欧地区。不幸的是，许多当地的犹太人死于纳粹的种族大屠杀，幸存者多数逃到了以色列，这些建筑大都已经荒废。

Even the smallest village can possess a temple. [PARAGRAPH:1]Facing Roman persecution, the earliest Christians worshiped in secret in private homes, catacombs, and the like. The Emperor Constantine I legalized Christianity in 325 AD. Though not a Christian himself as is often mistakenly claimed, Constantine I built many Christian churches across Roman territory, including the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, which many Christians believe is on the site where Jesus was born.

TEXT.English: In Civilization IV, a cathedral is defined as an especially large and ornate religious building where the faithful worship. Only the most prosperous cities can afford to create cathedrals, as they require huge amounts of raw material and years of dedicated labor by skilled craftsmen. For example, the Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris, France, took over two centuries to complete. [PARAGRAPH:1]Christian cathedrals are considered among the most beautiful buildings in the world. Many of the most imposing were built during the Middle Ages. Lofty buildings with beautiful stained glass, the early Christian cathedrals tended to collapse suddenly, with unfortunate results for those inside, until the invention of the flying buttress.

Monasteries usually have many daily rituals and religious services. [PARAGRAPH:1] Throughout the ages monasteries have often been centers of learning. [PARAGRAPH:1]The first recorded Christian monastery was founded by Saint Anthony in Egypt around 300 AD. The Roman Catholic Church has dozens of monastic orders, including the Benedictine, Franciscan, Jesuit, Carmelite, Trappist, Augustinian, and Knights Templar.

TEXT.English: The Church of the Nativity was built in Bethlehem, atop the place where Jesus was born. Constructed in 325 AD, burnt during the Samaritan Revolt in 529 and then rebuilt over the next 50 years, the Church is one of the oldest continuously operating Christian churches in the world. It is also one of the most fought over. Over time the Church has been held by Crusaders, Muslims, and various Christian sects. [PARAGRAPH:2]Externally, the Church represents more a fortress than it does a house of worship. It is surrounded by a thick stone wall with few windows or entrances. The Church is laid out in the typical Roman basilica design, with three aisles leading to a semicircular apse containing the altar. The main room once featured walls covered with golden mosaics, but is now somewhat fallen into decay. Beneath the Basilica lies the "Grotto of the Nativity," an underground cave covering the place where Jesus is said to have been born. The exact spot of Jesus' birth is marked by a silver star and surrounded by silver lamps.[PARAGRAPH:2]The compound containing the church is approximately 14,000 square yards in size. In addition to the Basilica, it contains a number of other important religious sites and three convents. [PARAGRAPH:2]Since its inception, Christianity has fragmented into a number of distinct sects. For many years these different groups have fought for control of the Church, and much blood has been shed on the sacred grounds. In recent years it has been administered by a coalition of Roman Catholic, Armenian and Greek Orthodox clerics, who in uneasy alliance make the Church available to all who wish to enter. Each year the Church is visited by thousands of Christian pilgrims. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Church's recent history has been as turbulent as it's past. The town of Bethlehem is in the West Bank of Palestine, which is periodically under Israeli occupation, and in 2002 the Church itself was occupied by 50 Palestinian fighters seeking refuge from Israeli defense forces. Somewhat miraculously the Church itself has suffered no damage in the recent conflicts, although the turmoil has greatly diminished the number of visitors to the site, which in turn limits the money available for its upkeep. [PARAGRAPH:2]Still, the Church remains one of Christianity's holiest of places, where God's only Son and the Savior of mankind entered the world.
TEXT.Chinese: 圣诞大教堂在耶稣的出生地伯利恒。建于公元325年，在529年撒马利亚起义期间被焚毁，又在其后50年重建，该教堂是世界上延续至今最古老的教堂之一，也是无数人竞相夺取的目标。在历史上，圣诞大教堂曾先后被十字军，穆斯林以及其他许多基督教政权所控制。[PARAGRAPH:2]圣诞大教堂的外观更象是一座要塞而不象是宗教场所。它由厚厚的石墙所围绕，只有很少几个门窗与外界相通。教堂的设计采用传统的罗马方堂建筑结构，有三条走廊通向放置圣坛的半圆形后殿。教堂主厅内墙一度全为黄金镶嵌，但现在已经不复存在。在教堂地基之下有“圣诞洞”，传说耶稣即降生于此。该处有一颗银星标示耶稣诞生的位置，周围环绕着许多银灯。[PARAGRAPH:2]整个建筑群占地约14,000平方码。除了教堂本身，还包括其他一些重要宗教设施和三座修女院。[PARAGRAPH:2]随着时间的推移，基督教逐渐分裂为多个不同教派。各教派间不断在争夺圣诞大教堂的控制权，在这片圣地之上流下了无数的鲜血。近年来，圣诞大教堂由罗马天主教会和亚美尼亚，希腊东正教会的神职人员联合管理，以尽可能满足所有人进入教堂的要求。每年都有成千上万的基督教朝圣者访问圣诞大教堂。[PARAGRAPH:2]现在的圣诞大教堂仍然象过去一样充满着动荡和不安。伯利恒市地处巴勒西坦约旦河西岸地区，目前在以色利的占领之下，在2002年时有50名巴勒斯坦武装人员进入教堂躲避以色利国防军的围捕。教堂在近几年中的武装冲突中能够保持完好无损，不能不说一个奇迹，但是紧张的局势使得访问者大量减少，造成教堂的维护资金日益紧缺。[PARAGRAPH:2]无论如何，圣诞大教堂仍然是基督教世界最重要的圣地之一，上帝唯一的爱子，人类拯救者就是在这里降生世间。

[PARAGRAPH:1]Islam has a great reverence for places of religious learning, no matter what religion. The Koran says, "Did not God check one people by means of another, there would surely have been pulled down monasteries, churches, synagogues and mosques, in which the name of God is commemorated in abundant measure."
TEXT.Chinese: 修道院是那些希望远离尘世，追求圣洁生活的宗教僧侣们的静修场所。通常修道院都规定有严格的行为准则，确保修道者免受外来的骚扰和诱惑。有的修道院要求人人保持静默；有的完全禁止访问者入内。僧侣们每日都须在修道院中举行宗教仪式。[PARAGRAPH:1]在古代，修道院往往也成为学术研究的中心。在边远地区，僧侣可能是当地仅有的有文化者。僧侣们经常担任抄写工作，负责传抄本宗教的经书文献。修道院通常会附有图书馆，用于存放神学、科学、医学和哲学书籍。[PARAGRAPH:1]伊斯兰教非常尊重信仰的学术研究，且不论其属于何种宗教。可兰经上说，“真主眼中的世人并无分别，不论是修道院、教堂、会堂还是清真寺，都是在全力敬奉真主之名。”

TEXT.English: The Masjid al-Haram is an Islamic mosque in the center of the holy city of Mecca, which is located in western Saudi Arabia. The mosque contains the Kaaba, an ancient cube-shaped building which is said to have been built by the Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham) and his son, Ishmael, at the orders of Allah, and which is believed to be the holiest place on Earth. The Kaaba in turn houses the "Black Stone," which it is said has fallen from heaven and has the power to cleanse worshippers of their sins. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Kaaba has always been revered as a holy place. Before the rise of Islam, the Kaaba was filled with idols, and Arabs from miles around came to worship there. Upon his return from exile, the Prophet Muhammad smashed the idols and rededicated the mosque to Allah and Islam. It has remained an Islamic holy place ever since and non-Muslims are forbidden to enter Mecca. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Masjid al-Haram is the focal point of the "hajj," a religious pilgrimage to Mecca required of all able-bodied Muslims (at least according to the Sunni sect). Every year during the holy month of Dhu'l-Hijjah, upwards of three million people visit the holy city and the most holy mosque within, thus fulfilling one of the "five pillars of Islam." The mosque has been enlarged and modernized to handle the extraordinary influx of faithful, but both the city and the mosque can barely handle the traffic. [PARAGRAPH:2]The mosque is in the form of a huge sprawling building surrounding a mighty courtyard with the Kaaba in the center. The building is extraordinarily beautiful and constructed of marble and porcelain and gold and bedecked with graceful minarets (towers). The interior is a wonder of columned halls filled with tapestries and other marvelous decorations. The courtyard itself is paved with marble. Truly a magnificent place of worship, Masjid al-Haram is said by some to surpass the Taj Mahal in glory and wonder.
TEXT.Chinese: 克尔白天房位于沙特阿拉伯西部的伊斯兰教圣城麦加市中心的阿尔-哈拉姆大清真寺（“禁寺”）内，是一座古老的方形建筑，传说为先知亚伯拉罕（易卜拉颀）及其子以实玛利依照安拉的命令所建造，是世界上最神圣的场所。天房中安放有一块“黑石”，据说来自天界，能使信徒消除自身的罪孽。[PARAGRAPH:2]自古以来克尔白天房就是一处圣地。在伊斯兰教兴起之前，天房中供奉着许多偶像，各处的阿拉伯人都前往该地祭拜。在先知穆罕默德经历流放生涯返回麦加之后，其中的偶像全被捣毁，成为专门敬奉安拉的伊斯兰清真寺。在此后，麦加一直是伊斯兰教的圣地，完全禁止非穆斯林进入。[PARAGRAPH:2]任何有能力的穆斯林在一生中都必须前往禁寺进行一次朝圣之旅（至少对于逊尼派来说）。在每年的朝圣月期间，总有超过三百万人前往圣城的禁寺，以完成“伊斯兰五功”之一（念、礼、斋、课、朝）。为此近年来禁寺不断进行扩建和现代代改造，但圣城和禁寺仍然是不堪重负。[PARAGRAPH:2]整座禁寺围绕着克尔白天房所在的大广场而建造。建筑风格极其精美，外部以大理石、陶瓷、黄金装饰，并点缀以数座尖塔。禁寺内大厅则密布挂毯等饰物。广场也完全以大理石铺成，是世上最豪华的宗教场所之一。许多人认为这座禁寺比泰姬玛哈陵还要更为宏伟壮观。

TEXT.English: In Civilization IV, a temple is defined as a building where the faithful come to worship. Christians call their temples "churches," while Muslims call theirs "mosques," and Jews call theirs, simply, "temples." Temples are far more common than cathedrals, but much less large and ornate. Even the smallest village can possess a temple. [PARAGRAPH:1]The word "mandir" is used to denote all Hindu places of worship. In Civilization IV, that term is reserved for the larger and more ornate buildings; smaller mandirs are called "temples." Typically, a Hindu temple is dedicated to a primary Hindu deity and that deity's subordinates. Worshipers must maintain a certain level of ritual purity to enter a temple: they must not wear footwear; they must not smoke, eat or drink inside; their breath should not smell of garlic or onions; and they may enter only with the priest's permission.
TEXT.Chinese: 在文明IV中，寺庙（或礼拜堂）被定义为宗教信徒进行宗教活动的建筑。基教徒称之为“礼拜堂”，穆斯林称之为“清真寺”，犹太人则简单地称之为“会堂”，此类建筑比大教堂更为常见，但规模及华丽程度则不及后者。甚至连最小的村庄也可能会拥有一座“寺庙”。[PARAGRAPH:1]印度教的宗教活动场所统称为神殿（“曼迪尔”）。为了在游戏中进行区分，这一名称用来专指更大型的印度教建筑；较小的印度教建筑则称为“神庙”。通常，印度教的神庙会供奉一位主神及一些次神。祭拜者进入神庙前必须做特定的净化仪式：不能穿鞋；不能其内吸烟或饮食；不能带有大蒜或洋葱的气味；而且进入前要先得到神职人员的允许。

TEXT.English: In Civilization IV, a cathedral is defined as an especially large and ornate religious building where the faithful worship. Only the most prosperous cities can afford to create cathedrals, as they require huge amounts of raw material and years of dedicated labor by skilled craftsmen. For example, the Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris, France, took over two centuries to complete. [PARAGRAPH:1]A "mandir" is the name used to describe all Hindu places of worship; used here it refers only to the larger and more important temples. Typically, a mandir is dedicated to a primary Hindu deity and other deities associated with that particular god, though in the US many different gods are worshiped in each mandir. The earliest mention of a mandir appears in the fifth century BC. The Angkor Wat, a Hindu temple built in the 12th Century AD, is one of the finest surviving Hindu mandirs in the world.
TEXT.Chinese: 在文明IV中，大教堂是指规模巨大，装饰华丽的宗教性建筑。只有非常繁荣的城市才有能力建造大教堂，因为此类建筑需要消耗大量原材料，并需要大批技艺精湛的工匠经年累月的努力。例如法国巴黎的圣母大教堂（巴黎圣母院）花费了两个世纪的时间才建造完成。[PARAGRAPH:1]印度教的宗教活动场所统称为神殿（“曼迪尔”）。为了在游戏中进行区分，这一名称用来专指更大型的印度教建筑；较小的印度教建筑则称为“神庙”。通常，印度教的神庙会供奉一位主神及一些从属的次神，但在美国的印度教神殿往往会同时供奉多个神灵。最早的印度教神殿出现于公元前五世纪。建造于12世纪的吴哥窟是世界上最宏伟的印度教神殿之一。

TEXT.English: A monastery is a building where monks can retreat from the world and concentrate upon the divine. Usually a monastery will have strict rules of conduct to protect its unworldly members from temptation. In some monasteries, the monks are totally silent; in others no visitors are allowed inside. Monasteries usually have many daily rituals and religious services. [PARAGRAPH:1] Throughout the ages monasteries have often been centers of learning. In remote areas the monks may be the only literate people for miles around. Monks have often been employed as scribes, copying out the words of their religion's sacred scripture. Monasteries frequently have extensive libraries, holding religious, scientific, medical and philosophical texts. [PARAGRAPH:1]Hindu monasteries have been constructed across India and Asia. Many were built in remote places, far from the ravages of war and conquest; some survive today virtually untouched by history.
TEXT.Chinese: 修道院是那些希望远离尘世，追求圣洁生活的宗教僧侣们的静修场所。通常修道院都规定有严格的行为准则，确保修道者免受外来的骚扰和诱惑。有的修道院要求人人保持静默；有的完全禁止访问者入内。僧侣们每日都须在修道院中举行宗教仪式。[PARAGRAPH:1]在古代，修道院往往也成为学术研究的中心。在边远地区，僧侣可能是当地仅有的有文化者。僧侣们经常担任抄写工作，负责传抄本宗教的经书文献。修道院通常会附有图书馆，用于存放神学、科学、医学和哲学书籍。[PARAGRAPH:1]印度教静修院分布于印度和亚洲其他地区。此类建筑常常位于边远地区，以避免战火的侵扰；许多古老的静修院一直存在至今。

TEXT.English: Kashi Vishwanath was a temple located in Varanasi, "the oldest living city in the world," and the place most sacred to Hinduism. The origins of Varanasi are shrouded in history, but it is believed that the city is more than 3000 years old. After visiting the city, Mark Twain wrote that Varanasi "is older than history, older than tradition, older even than legend and looks twice as old as all of them put together."[PARAGRAPH:2]According to Hindu tradition Varanasi is the home of Lord Shiva and his consort, Parvati. Known as the Destroyer, Lord Shiva is part of the "trimurti" - the three aspects of God - creation, preservation, and destruction. Shiva's consort Parvati is seen as Earth Mother, and, according to tradition, the two are the parents of all living creatures. The city is also held sacred because it is here that the Ganges River gained the power to wash away sins. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Kashi Vishwanath is a golden temple standing at the city's center. The date of construction of the original temple is not known. It was destroyed in 1669 by the Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb, who built a mosque atop the ruins. The present Kashi Vishwanath was built in 1776, across the street from its original location. The newer building's spire is about 50 feet in height and covered with over one ton of gold plating, donated by Maharaja Ranjit Singh. The temple's interior consists of a mandapa (pillared hall) and a sanctum containing a silver altar. [PARAGRAPH:2]According to Hindu tradition, it was here that the first jyotirlinga, the fiery pillar of light by which Shiva manifested his supremacy over other Gods, broke through the earth's crust and flared towards the heavens. The altar contains a Shivalinga (an ancient symbol of Shiva) in its center to commemorate this event. It is believed that viewing the temple can transform a worshipper's life and put him on the path of knowledge and devotion, and each year the temple is visited by tens of thousands of Hindu faithful seeking enlightment.
TEXT.Chinese: 黄金殿位于印度瓦拉纳西，“世界上现存最古老的城市”，是最神圣的印度教建筑。虽然瓦拉纳西最初的建造年代已不可考，但据信它拥有超过3000年的建城史。马克吐温在访问该城之后写道，瓦拉纳西“比历史更古老，比传统更古老，甚至也比传奇更古老，后三者的年龄加起来也不及它一半古老。”[PARAGRAPH:2]根据印度教传说，瓦拉纳西是湿婆大神及其妻室巴瓦娣的居所。作为破坏之神，湿婆是“三相神”——三位一体的主神——创造之神，保护之神，以及破坏之神。而巴瓦娣则被视为大地之母，传说两者创造了世上所有的生命。这座城市之所以神圣，还因为城畔的恒河拥有洗刷所有罪恶的神力。[PARAGRAPH:2]黄金殿位于瓦拉纳亚市中心。该神殿最初的建造年代已不可考，1669年时曾被莫卧儿皇帝奥朗则布所摧毁，并在原址建造了一座清真寺。现存的黄金殿建于1776年，与原址隔街相望。新殿尖顶高50英尺，由重达一吨的黄金覆盖，系由当地王公拉吉特·辛格所捐赠。神殿由主大厅和放置银制圣坛的后厅构成。[PARAGRAPH:2]根据印度教传说，第一块“究提林迦”（意为光之圣石，湿婆用以胜过其他诸神的宝物）就是在神殿圣坛所在位置射出大地直达天界的。圣坛现放置着湿婆林迦（湿婆神的标志）以纪念这一事件。信徒们认为进入黄金殿可使人获得智慧和忠诚，因此每年都有无数印度教徒前来朝拜以寻求神的启示。

Christians call their temples "churches," while Muslims call theirs "mosques," and Jews call theirs, simply, "temples." Temples are far more common than cathedrals, but much less large and ornate. Even the smallest village can possess a temple. [PARAGRAPH:1]Buddhist temples are places of worship, meditation and study; they can be found across the world. The oldest surviving Buddhist temples are in India, where the religion was first founded.

Only the most prosperous cities can afford to create cathedrals, as they require huge amounts of raw material and years of dedicated labor by skilled craftsmen. For example, the Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris, France, took over two centuries to complete. [PARAGRAPH:1]Buddhist stupas are monuments holding holy relics. The first eight stupas were created to hold the Buddha's remains. During his reign, the Emperor Asoka took portions of the Buddha's ashes and spread them among the thousands of stupas he created. Stupas can now be found across Asia and the world. [PARAGRAPH:1]The oldest surviving stupa can be found in Sanchi, India. The "Great Stupa" was constructed by Emperor Asoka some time in the third century BC.

TEXT.English: A monastery is a building where monks can retreat from the world and concentrate upon the divine. Usually a monastery will have strict rules of conduct to protect its unworldly members from temptation. In some monasteries, the monks are totally silent; in others no visitors are allowed inside. Monasteries usually have many daily rituals and religious services. [PARAGRAPH:1] Throughout the ages monasteries have often been centers of learning. In remote areas the monks may be the only literate people for miles around. Monks have often been employed as scribes, copying out the words of their religion's sacred scripture. Monasteries frequently have extensive libraries, holding religious, scientific, medical and philosophical texts. [PARAGRAPH:1]Buddhist monasteries were originally created to provide places for the wandering Buddhist monks to make their annual retreats. Some Buddhist monks stay indoors during the three-month rainy season to avoid damaging new plant growth (and to avoid being stranded during inclement weather). In the past, wealthy supporters donated plots of land where the monks could retreat; over time these have evolved into monasteries, often large and wealthy structures where monks can live year round.

TEXT.English: Located near Patna, in Bihar state, India, the Mahabodhi is a Buddhist temple in Bodh Gaya, the place where, according to Buddhist tradition, Siddhartha Gautama gained enlightenment and became the Buddha while meditating under a Bodhi (Peepal) tree. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Emperor Asoka constructed the "Golden Throne" sometime around 250 BC, and over time many other buildings and statues were added. In the 12th century the area was overrun by Muslims, and the temple sacked and largely destroyed. In the 16th century a Hindu monastery was established, and the monastery's abbot was given control over the temple grounds. [PARAGRAPH:2]Eventually the area came under British control. In the 1880s they began a major restoration of the temple, much against the wishes of the Hindu abbot. In the 1940s control over the site was given to the state, which manages the site with the advice of a committee containing Buddhists from the world over. [PARAGRAPH:2]A building of remarkable beauty and grandeur, the Mahabodhi is one of the oldest surviving brick buildings in India. Standing on the ruins of an even older "stupa," the temple consists of a high central tower surrounded by four smaller towers. The central tower rises some 60 feet in height. The edifice is covered by ornate and colorful molding, pilasters (pseudo columns), and arches, many of which contain bas relief sculptures. Inside sits a very large gilded statue of the Buddha. The statue sits where, legend has it, the Buddha was sitting when he achieved enlightenment. [PARAGRAPH:2]Near to the building stands a mighty Bodhi tree, a descendant of the one under which Buddha found enlightenment. The temple stands within an extensive complex of smaller temples, statues, and pathways running through beautiful parklands and alongside peaceful lakes. The temple and its surroundings remain a focus of Buddhist worship, and people from across the world come every year to honor the Buddha and to marvel at the beauty of the Mahabodhi.
TEXT.Chinese: 大菩提寺坐落于印度比哈尔邦的巴特那附近，是一座佛教寺庙。根据佛教的传说，佛教创始人乔达摩·悉达多就是在那里的一棵菩提树下进行冥想时突然大彻大悟，从而成佛。[PARAGRAPH:2]阿育王于公元前250年左右建造了“黄金王座”，随后的时间里，陆续建造了许多其他建筑和雕像。12世纪穆斯林蹂躏了这里，寺庙遭到洗劫，大部分被毁。16世纪这里成了一座印度教的神庙，这一带也被印度教徒所控制。[PARAGRAPH:2]后来该地区又落入英国人之手。19世纪80年代，这座寺庙进行了大规模的修复，虽然这遭到了许多印度教僧侣们抵制。20世纪40年代，这一地区的控制权被移交给了政府。并根据来自全世界佛教徒组成的委员会的意见管理着这座寺庙。[PARAGRAPH:2]大菩提寺非常美丽庄严，是印度现存最古老的砖砌建筑。建立于一座更古老的佛塔的废墟之上，这座寺庙拥有一座中央高塔，四面还有四座小塔。中央塔大约有60英尺高。整座建筑遍布绚丽多彩的壁柱和拱顶。上面还有大量的浮雕。内部有很大的镀金佛像。这是一尊坐像，据说佛祖在得道之后就是坐化的。[PARAGRAPH:2]在建筑附近有一棵很大的菩提树，据说是佛祖得道那棵树的后代。寺庙附近有大量的小寺庙，雕像和道路，穿过那些如茵的绿地，旁边是宁静的湖泊。寺庙和其附近的建筑仍然是佛教徒们膜拜的圣地，每年有无数人从世界各地来到这里膜拜佛祖，并欣赏着大菩提寺的美丽风光。

TEXT.English: In Civilization IV, a temple is defined as a building where the faithful come to worship. Christians call their temples "churches," while Muslims call theirs "mosques," and Jews call theirs, simply, "temples." Temples are far more common than cathedrals, but much less large and ornate. Even the smallest village can possess a temple. [PARAGRAPH:1]Though Confucius himself was a philosopher rather than a religious leader, over time he was accorded the status of a god and worshipped across Asia. Many temples to Confucius were constructed, some small and private, others more extensive where hundreds of worshippers could attend services. Many Confucian temples were constructed in the pagoda style of architecture.
TEXT.Chinese: 在文明IV中，寺庙（或礼拜堂）被定义为宗教信徒进行宗教活动的建筑。基教徒称之为“礼拜堂”，穆斯林称之为“清真寺”，犹太人则简单地称之为“会堂”，此类建筑比大教堂更为常见，但规模及华丽程度则不及后者。甚至连最小的村庄也可能会拥有一座“寺庙”。[PARAGRAPH:1]虽然孔子本人是一位哲学家而非宗教领袖，但随着时间的推移，他的地位逐渐变得神圣起来，在亚洲的许多国家均为民众所崇拜。各处都建造了祭祀孔子的建筑（除用于祭祀外也是宣讲儒学场所），有些规模较小，称为学馆。有些则宏伟堂皇，称为学宫，所有此类建筑大都采用中国传统的飞檐斗拱的建筑形式。

TEXT.English: A monastery is a building where monks can retreat from the world and concentrate upon the divine. Usually a monastery will have strict rules of conduct to protect its unworldly members from temptation. In some monasteries, the monks are totally silent; in others no visitors are allowed inside. Monasteries usually have many daily rituals and religious services. [PARAGRAPH:1] Throughout the ages monasteries have often been centers of learning. In remote areas the monks may be the only literate people for miles around. Monks have often been employed as scribes, copying out the words of their religion's sacred scripture. Monasteries frequently have extensive libraries, holding religious, scientific, medical and philosophical texts. [PARAGRAPH:1]For centuries Confucianism was the state religion of China, and the Imperial Court regularly included Confucians in positions of authority and power. Thus, many Confucian monasteries were constructed under Imperial sponsorship.
TEXT.Chinese: 修道院是那些希望远离尘世，追求圣洁生活的宗教僧侣们的静修场所。通常修道院都规定有严格的行为准则，确保修道者免受外来的骚扰和诱惑。有的修道院要求人人保持静默；有的完全禁止访问者入内。僧侣们每日都须在修道院中举行宗教仪式。[PARAGRAPH:1]在古代，修道院往往也成为学术研究的中心。在边远地区，僧侣可能是当地仅有的有文化者。僧侣们经常担任抄写工作，负责传抄本宗教的经书文献。修道院通常会附有图书馆，用于存放神学、科学、医学和哲学书籍。[PARAGRAPH:1]在数千年间，儒学一直是中国的官方信仰，朝庭大量任用儒士担任政府官职。许多儒学书院都获得官方的资助。

TEXT.English: In Civilization IV, a cathedral is defined as an especially large and ornate religious building where the faithful worship. Only the most prosperous cities can afford to create cathedrals, as they require huge amounts of raw material and years of dedicated labor by skilled craftsmen. For example, the Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris, France, took over two centuries to complete. [PARAGRAPH:1]Many of the early Confucian religious buildings were destroyed during the Qin Dynasty. When the Emperor Wu (156-87 BC) adopted Confucianism as the state religion of China, he placed many Confucian scholars in positions of power; eventually, knowledge of Confucianism became a prerequisite for anyone hoping to gain employment in the Imperial government. Private and public Confucian Academies sprung up across China, where families sent their sons to study for the civil service examinations.
TEXT.Chinese: 在文明IV中，大教堂是指规模巨大，装饰华丽的宗教性建筑。只有非常繁荣的城市才有能力建造大教堂，因为此类建筑需要消耗大量原材料，并需要大批技艺精湛的工匠经年累月的努力。例如法国巴黎的圣母大教堂（巴黎圣母院）花费了两个世纪的时间才建造完成。[PARAGRAPH:1]许多早期的儒学建筑在秦朝时遭到焚毁。在汉武帝统治时期（前156-前87），儒学被尊为官方信仰，他任用了许多大儒执掌朝政；最终，熟悉儒学经典成为在朝廷和地方担任官职的基本前提。私人或官办的儒学教育机构（学宫）遍布全国，许多年轻人在其中读书求学，为通过各级科举考试而努力。

TEXT.English: The Kong Miao, or Temple of Confucius, is located in the city Qufu in China's Shandong province. The origins of the temple date back to 478 BC, when a local ruler built a temple to honor Confucius (who had only recently passed away and was relatively unknown in most of China). As time passed and the fame of Confucius began to spread, the Kong Miao grew in stature and importance as well. The Han Emperor Wu Di offered sacrifices at the site in 205 BC, and the Kong Miao continued to be patronized by various emperors across the centuries. [PARAGRAPH:1]The actual buildings that make up the Kong Miao have been torn down and rebuilt many times over the centuries. The present layout dates to the early 16th century, when the temple was rebuilt following a massive conflaguration in 1499 sparked by lightning. Since this construction took place at the same time as Beijing's Forbidden Palace, there are many design similarities between the two complexes. The Kong Miao is known not only for its size (it comprises some 466 rooms), but also for its stone sculptures and calligraphy dating back to many different dynasties. Today it is both a holy Confucian shrine and a popular tourist attraction.
TEXT.Chinese: 孔庙，即孔氏宗庙，坐落于中国山东省曲阜县境内。该庙的起源可上溯到公元前478年，当时的一位地方统治者建立了这座庙纪念孔子（那时他刚刚去世，在大部分中国尚不为人知）。随着时间的流逝，孔子的盛名开始广为流传，孔庙的规模和地位也不断扩大。汉武帝于公元前205年首次在该庙献祭，此后的数百年间孔庙不断地得到各位帝王们的资助。[PARAGRAPH:1]构成孔庙的建筑在数百年里多次被毁坏而又重建。现存的建筑约建造于16世纪早期，当时寺庙毁于1499年的一次雷击引起的大火。该建筑与北京的紫禁城建于同一时期，因而两者的设计中有许多相似之处。孔庙不仅因其建筑规模宏大而著名（共有房屋466间），而且拥有大量不同时代的书法和石刻。今天这里不但是儒家的圣地，也是广受欢迎的游览胜地。

TEXT.English: In Civilization IV, a temple is defined as a building where the faithful come to worship. Christians call their temples "churches," while Muslims call theirs "mosques," and Jews call theirs, simply, "temples." Temples are far more common than cathedrals, but much less large and ornate. Even the smallest village can possess a temple. [PARAGRAPH:1]Taoist temples are often attractive, brightly-colored buildings, filled with statues of divine beings. Priests may or may not be in attendance. Taoism is a ritualistic religion, and the temple is often used for ceremonies ranging from parades to exorcisms. The ceremonies themselves tend to be loud and colorful, full of chanting, singing, clashing symbols, and firecrackers.
TEXT.Chinese: 在文明IV中，寺庙（或礼拜堂）被定义为宗教信徒进行宗教活动的建筑。基教徒称之为“礼拜堂”，穆斯林称之为“清真寺”，犹太人则简单地称之为“会堂”，此类建筑比大教堂更为常见，但规模及华丽程度则不及后者。甚至连最小的村庄也可能会拥有一座“寺庙”。[PARAGRAPH:1]道教建筑称为道观，一般而言装饰精美，设有许多神仙塑像。通常会有修道之士居住其中。教道非常注重礼仪，道观经常会举行各种各样的仪式，或为传道，或为驱魔。举行此类仪式时往往钟鼓礼乐齐备，喧闹非凡。

TEXT.English: A monastery is a building where monks can retreat from the world and concentrate upon the divine. Usually a monastery will have strict rules of conduct to protect its unworldly members from temptation. In some monasteries, the monks are totally silent; in others no visitors are allowed inside. Monasteries usually have many daily rituals and religious services. [PARAGRAPH:1] Throughout the ages monasteries have often been centers of learning. In remote areas the monks may be the only literate people for miles around. Monks have often been employed as scribes, copying out the words of their religion's sacred scripture. Monasteries frequently have extensive libraries, holding religious, scientific, medical and philosophical texts. [PARAGRAPH:1]Taoists began constructing monasteries during the Tang period, from 600 - 900 BC. They learned the concept of monasticism from the Buddhists, who greatly influenced Taoism during this period.
TEXT.Chinese: 修道院是那些希望远离尘世，追求圣洁生活的宗教僧侣们的静修场所。通常修道院都规定有严格的行为准则，确保修道者免受外来的骚扰和诱惑。有的修道院要求人人保持静默；有的完全禁止访问者入内。僧侣们每日都须在修道院中举行宗教仪式。[PARAGRAPH:1]在古代，修道院往往也成为学术研究的中心。在边远地区，僧侣可能是当地仅有的有文化者。僧侣们经常担任抄写工作，负责传抄本宗教的经书文献。修道院通常会附有图书馆，用于存放神学、科学、医学和哲学书籍。[PARAGRAPH:1]在公元7至10世纪，李唐王朝十分尊奉教道，大批道院开始兴建起来。这一时期的道教也不断借鉴佛教的经验而日趋成熟。

TEXT.English: In Civilization IV, a cathedral is defined as an especially large and ornate religious building where the faithful worship. Only the most prosperous cities can afford to create cathedrals, as they require huge amounts of raw material and years of dedicated labor by skilled craftsmen. For example, the Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris, France, took over two centuries to complete. [PARAGRAPH:1]Many of the most elaborate and extensive Taoist religious buildings are pagodas - tiered towers with multiple eaves. This building style originated in Nepal and has since spread across much of Asia. Unfortunately, many great Taoist pagodas were constructed of wood - wood holds special religious significance for Taoists - and have not withstood the onslaught of time. [PARAGRAPH:1]Taoist pagodas tend to be bright and colorful structures, with broad curving roofs that are adorned with divine figures and traditional symbols of luck such as dragons and carp. Taoism is not a selfish faith, and the pagodas may have rooms or shrines dedicated to Buddhist meditation and/or Hindu deities.
TEXT.Chinese: 在文明IV中，大教堂是指规模巨大，装饰华丽的宗教性建筑。只有非常繁荣的城市才有能力建造大教堂，因为此类建筑需要消耗大量原材料，并需要大批技艺精湛的工匠经年累月的努力。例如法国巴黎的圣母大教堂（巴黎圣母院）花费了两个世纪的时间才建造完成。[PARAGRAPH:1]规模宏伟的道宫大都是重檐斗拱的多层楼阁。不幸的是，大多数道宫均用木料建造——道教信仰以林木为尊——难以经受时间的摧残。[PARAGRAPH:1]道教殿宇非常华丽精美，在屋脊和拱梁上通常装饰有大量神仙雕像以及传统吉祥图案，例如盘龙和阴阳鱼等。道教是一种兼容并蓄的信仰，在道宫中也会建有佛教僧人的禅室或是来自于印度教神灵的塑像。

TEXT.English: The Taoist Dai Miao, or "Temple of the God of Mount Tai," is located on Mount Tai in Shandong Province, China. One of the "five sacred mountains of China," Mount Tai has been of great religious importance throughout Chinese history, and evidence suggests that pilgrims have been climbing the mountain for at least 3000 years. There are 22 temples, 97 ruins, and several thousand stone tablets and inscriptions scattered across the its rugged shoulders.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Dai Miao is the largest temple complex on the mountain, covering an area of about a million square feet. The buildings within the temple have been built and rebuilt a number of times, the most recent major overhaul occurring about 2000 years ago during the Han Dynasty. [PARAGRAPH:2]In its latest incarnation, the temple is a replica of the Imperial Palace. The complex has five major halls and many small buildings. The most important building is the Palace of Heavenly Blessings, constructed in 1008. The building contains a mural titled, "The God of Mount Tai Making a Journey." The mural is 10 feet in height by about 200 feet long. It was painted in 1009, making it 1004 years old. [PARAGRAPH:2]Next to the Palace of Heavenly Blessings stand the Yaocan Pavilion and the entrance archway, as well as the Bronze Pavilion in the northeast corner. The Dai Temple is surrounded by the 2,100 year-old Han Dynasty cypresses. Beloved as much for its rugged beauty as for its religious significance, the Dai Miao remains one of the most important religious structures in the world.
TEXT.Chinese: 道教圣地岱庙（或称岱岳庙、东岳庙、泰庙），即“东岳大帝（泰山之神）的庙宇”，坐落于中国山东省的泰山，该山是中国的五岳之一，在中国历史上，泰山在宗教上具有非常的重要性。朝圣者们参拜该山已经有至少3000年历史了，泰山上现有22座庙，另有97处废墟，数千座石碑和题字散布于崎岖的山间。[PARAGRAPH:2]岱庙是泰山上规模最大的建筑群，占地一百万平方英尺。庙中的建筑历经数次重建，最近一次大规模重修是在大约2000年前的汉代。[PARAGRAPH:2]它的最近一次修缮是仿照帝王宫殿的一次复制。整个建筑群拥有五座大厅和许多较小的建筑。最重要的建筑是宋天贶殿，建于1008年。殿内有一巨幅壁画:“泰山神启跸回銮图”，高约10英尺，长约200英尺，绘于1009年，已有1000年的历史。[PARAGRAPH:2]天贶殿旁边是遥参亭和一座拱门，另有一座“金阙”（铜亭）位于东南角。岱庙周围还环绕着植于2100多年前的汉柏。[PARAGRAPH:2]岱庙以其历经沧桑的美丽和宗教代表性，成为世界上最重要的宗教建筑之一。

TEXT.English: An "epic" is a heroic poem celebrating the life and achievements of a heroic individual or group. Classic examples of epics include Homer's "Iliad" and "Odyssey." [PARAGRAPH:1]A "national epic" celebrates the exploits of an entire country. One of the earliest examples is the "Shahnama," (The Book of Kings), a Persian literary classic written around 1000 AD. The Shahnama chronicles the history of Persia from mythological pre-history through the reign of Khosrau II (590-628). The work contains over 60,000 couplets and is still read and enjoyed by modern readers. [PARAGRAPH:1]It is possible that the age of the literary epic is dead, and that in the future all such stories will be done as "made for TV movies." This would be a great misfortune to the world of letters - and to the rest of the world, as well.
TEXT.Chinese: “史诗”是歌颂某一位或某一群人的生平和功绩的英雄诗歌。史诗中的经典例子是荷马的“伊里亚特”和“奥德赛”。[PARAGRAPH:1]民族史诗歌颂的则是整个国家的开发，最早的例子之一是“王书”（国王之书），为创作于公元1000年左右的波斯文学经典。王书记载了波斯从史前的神话时代一直到库思劳二世在位期间（590-628）。这部作品大约有60,000行，今天仍为读者们所喜好。[PARAGRAPH:1]文学史诗的时代已经永远过去了，将来这种故事将都是“为影视剧而创作”。对于文字世界来说这可能是个巨大的不幸——对整个世界来说，也许同样如此。

TEXT.English: Located in St. Petersburg, Russia, the Hermitage is one of the oldest and most important art galleries in the world. The collection was begun in 1764, when Catherine of Russia purchased more than 200 paintings from across Europe. The collection was, of course, private; Catherine nicknamed her collection "my hermitage" (meaning hermit home), because only she and the mice got to see it. The New Hermitage building was built by Tsar Nicholas I; he opened it to the public in 1852. [PARAGRAPH:1]Renovated many times to hold an ever-expanding collection, the Hermitage now spans some six buildings overlooking the Neva River. The buildings themselves are extraordinarily beautiful, their huge hallways and opulent rooms fitting places for one of the world's great art collections. [PARAGRAPH:1]The art collection itself is almost beyond superlatives. It contains an extensive collection of Russian Imperial regalia and Faberge jewelry. It includes masterpieces from Greek and Roman eras and beyond into antiquity. It also houses one of the best collections of Rembrandt paintings anywhere. It has multiple works by da Vinci. In all, the Hermitage houses more than three million pieces of outstanding artwork from throughout human history.
TEXT.Chinese: 坐落在俄国圣彼得堡的冬宫（即爱尔米塔什博物馆），是世界上历史最悠久，也是最著名的美术馆之一。其收藏活动开始于1764年，当时沙皇叶卡捷琳娜从欧洲购买了200多件绘画作品。当然，这些收藏都是私人所有；叶卡捷琳娜把她的收藏戏称为“我的爱尔米塔什”（意即隐士的居所），因为只有她和老鼠们才能见到它们。新的冬宫建造于沙皇尼古拉一世时期；在1852年，沙皇开始允许公众参观。[PARAGRAPH:1]经过几次大的扩建和修复，爱尔米塔什博物馆已经扩大成为沿着涅瓦河畔矗立着的六座建筑组成的大型建筑群。这些建筑本身都极为漂亮，它们那巨大的门廊，富裕的房间数量都让它成为了世界上最大的美术馆之一。[PARAGRAPH:1]它的艺术品收藏是极为丰富的。拥有丰富的俄国王室礼服及费伯奇珠宝的收藏。也有古希腊和古罗马时期以及更早时代的艺术杰作。这里也是大画家伦勃朗作品收藏最多的地方。达芬奇的很多作品也能在这里见到。总之，这座博物馆拥有人类历史长河遗留下来的超过三百万件的杰作。

TEXT.English: The Epic of Gilgamesh documents the adventures of this Middle Eastern hero. Of special interest to biblical scholars, the document was found among the ruins of Nineveh. More than 3000 lines, scribed across 12 tablets, this tale was written around 2000 BC. Gilgamesh was a king of Uruk, which now lies within the borders of Iraq.
TEXT.Chinese: 史诗《吉尔伽美什》叙述了古代中东的英雄吉尔伽美什的冒险事迹。19世纪中叶，一位研究圣经的学者在古代亚述首都尼尼微城的废墟之中找到了刻写着这篇完成于公元前2000年，全长超过3000行的史诗的12块石板。吉尔伽美什是乌鲁克的国王，这个王国位于今伊拉克境内。

TEXT.English: Most of the plays of William Shakespeare were first performed on the stage of London's Globe Theater during the 1600s. Theaters offered people a diversion from their everyday lives by allowing them to enjoy comedies, tragedies, and triumphs acted out on stage. Similar theaters, such as the Comedie Francaise in Paris, and La Scala in Milan, fulfilled similar roles by offering entertainment to the citizens of their cities. Although the original Globe Theater burned down, Shakespeare's plays are still performed in a new theater bearing his name, and in other theaters throughout the world.
TEXT.Chinese: 大多数威廉·莎士比亚的戏剧都于17世纪在伦敦的环球剧场首度公演。剧场使人们通过欣赏悲剧，喜剧的剧情和舞台上成功的表演从平淡无奇的日常生活中获得娱乐。类似的剧场，例如巴黎的弗兰凯斯剧场，米兰的拉斯卡拉剧场亦以类似的方式娱乐大众。尽管最早的环球剧场被大火焚毁，然而莎士比亚的戏剧却还在以他的名字命名的剧场和全世界的各大剧场中持续上演。

TEXT.English: The location of the New York Stock Exchange, Wall Street has become the epitome of the modern financial district. A narrow street running from Broadway to the East River, it houses some of the world's most prestigious and powerful banks and commodity exchanges. In 1653 Dutch colonists erected a barricade along this route to ward off the British and unfriendly natives.
TEXT.Chinese: 作为纽约证卷交易所的所在地，华尔街已经成为现代世界经济状况的指标。这条从百老汇大街至东河的狭窄街道上汇集了一大批世界上声誉最盛，实力最强的银行及商品交易所。“华尔”的原意是“墙”，1653年，荷兰殖民者曾沿这条路建造高墙，以将英国人和不友好的原住民拒之墙外。

TEXT.English: As mankind's dependence on metals increased through the ages, it became very important to cheaply and effectively separate the base metal from impurities. The process of smelting, through the use of a structure called a blast furnace, achieved just that. Using carbon dioxide created from oxidized coke to absorb the oxygen from the molten iron, it leaves the metal slag to sink to the bottom of the furnace. This separation allows for a pure iron to be derived, which is then used for numerous purposes, including the creation of steel.
TEXT.Chinese: 在人类致力于提高金属产量的时代里，如何将金属从杂质中廉价高效的分离出来成为一个非常重要的问题。一般是通过使用一种称为鼓风熔炉的设备使熔炼的过程达到这个要求。利用氧化反应，使用炭吸收熔化的铁中的氧而生成二氧化碳，在熔炉底便留下纯净的铁。这个分离使人们得以炼出纯铁，纯铁可用于炼钢等多种目的。

TEXT.English: Methods of passing down the tactics and arts of war from generation to generation vary based on culture and era. The United States' solution, which up to that point relied on foreign instructors, lay in creating the United States Military Academy, located at West Point, New York. Established in 1802 on the site of a 18th century fortress, West Point went on to train most of the nation's military leaders. Cadets are selected for training via a diverse number of methods, including competitive and non-competitive methods. Graduates earn the commission of Second Lieutenants and receive a Bachelor of Science degree. One paramount function of this institution is to stay current in the practice of warfare, typically by having officers from previous conflicts become instructors.
TEXT.Chinese: 将战术和军事艺术流传下去的方式依照地域和时代的不同而不同。美国的做法是聘用外籍教师，并设立专门的军事学院。该军事学院位于纽约的西点。以一座建于18世纪的要塞为主体建筑逐渐发展而来。始建于1802年。西点军校造就了美国的大多数军事领袖。学员在这座学院内接受多种训练。毕业后直接获得少尉军衔及理科学士学位。学校的最大特色在于不断更新教学课程以适应现代战争的要求，尤其是聘请经过多次战争考验的前任军官作为讲师。

TEXT.English: Mount Rushmore stands as one of the largest sculpted structures in modern human history. Mount Rushmore displays in granite the heads of four great US presidents: George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Abraham Lincoln, and Theodore Roosevelt. Each head stands approximately 60 feet in height. [PARAGRAPH:2]Mount Rushmore was the vision of Doane Robinson, the superintendent of the South Dakota Historical Society. He engaged the famous American sculptor Gutzon Borglum to take charge of the project. For fourteen years Borglum and a team of 400 local miners blasted, chiseled, scraped and polished the granite mountain until the work was finally completed in 1941. Most remarkably, no one was killed during construction. [PARAGRAPH:2]Mount Rushmore has been called the "American Shrine." Each year thousands journey to the rugged mountains of South Dakota to look upon their four great leaders.
TEXT.Chinese: 总统山（拉什莫尔山）可以算是现代历史中最大的雕刻建筑之一。总统山以花岗岩显示了四位美国总统的头像：乔治·华盛顿，托马斯·杰斐逊，亚伯拉罕·林肯，西奥多·罗斯福。每个头像大约60英尺高。[PARAGRAPH:2]总统山的设想来自于南达科塔历史学会的负责人多安尼·罗宾逊。他让美国著名雕刻家古特松·波格鲁姆负责这个计划。波格鲁姆率领400名当地矿工队伍花了14年时间，在花岗岩上凿刮刻抛光，最后工程于1941年完工。值得注意的是，没有一个人死于工程事故。[PARAGRAPH:2]总统山被称为“美利坚圣坛”。每年都有成千上万的旅游者来到南达科塔崎岖的山地来瞻仰他们的伟大领袖。
