TEXT.English: The University of Oxford, England, is the oldest university in the English-speaking world. It is also one of the most prestigious. The exact date of the university's founding is unknown, but scholars believe it was some time around 1100 AD. [PARAGRAPH:1]Oxford is made up of 39 colleges and seven "permanent private halls" (which are religious organizations). Each is housed in a separate building usually built in a square around a quadrangle. The colleges generally consist of a great hall, a chapel, a library, a bar, several common rooms, classrooms, and lodging for around 300 students. Built in the 1250s, Balliol, Merton, and University Colleges are among the oldest. [PARAGRAPH:1]For most of its existence, Oxford has been one of the world's great universities, and it remains so to this day. Many famous people have passed through its halls, including four English and eight foreign kings, over 50 presidents and prime ministers (including US President William Clinton), 47 Nobel Prize winners, and one pope.
TEXT.Chinese: 英国牛津大学是英语世界中最古老的一座大学。它也有极高的声望。大学建立的确切时间无人知晓，但是学者们认为大约是在公元1100年左右。[PARAGRAPH:1]牛津大学由39个学院组成，还有七个“永久私人学院”（由教会设立）。每一个都是相对独立的，通常各拥有一个方形庭院。每个学院由主会堂、礼拜堂、图书馆、酒吧、一些普通房间、教室以及可住300名学生的宿舍组成。在13世纪50年代建成的巴利奥尔，默顿以及综合学院是其中最为古老的几个。[PARAGRAPH:1]在牛津大学建成之后，它始终位于世界上最好的大学行列中，直至今日依然如此。许多名人曾经徜徉在牛津的厅堂之间，其中包括四位英格兰国王和八位其他国家的国王，超过50位总统与首相（总理），包括美国总统克林顿，47位诺贝尔奖获得者，还有一位教皇。

TEXT.English: While fundamentally in conflict with the destructive goals of war, physicians must still proffer aid to those in need. The practice of repairing the personal damage of war, sometimes actually during the fight itself, has a number of benefits beyond the obvious. A paramount one is that of morale, since the soldiers of an army that contains surgeons are assured care if they fall in battle.
TEXT.Chinese: 虽然同“战争以毁灭为最终目的”之原则相违背，外科医生仍在战场上向那些需要帮助的人提供救治。对伤员的救助往往超出其本身的意义，其中极为重要的一点，就是对士气的鼓舞作用。因为拥有外科医生的话，士兵们会相信，哪怕他们在战场上倒下，也会有人救助他们。

TEXT.English: Scotland Yard is the name of the British police force having jurisdiction over the Greater London area. Scotland Yard is named for the neighborhood in which the original police headquarters stood, and the force retains that nickname even though the headquarters have since been relocated (to "New Scotland Yard"). [PARAGRAPH:1]Scotland Yard was established in 1829 by act of Parliament. According to one of the new force's commissioners, "The primary object of an efficient police is the prevention of crime: the next that of detection and punishment of offenders if crime is committed. To these ends all the efforts of police must be directed. The protection of life and property, the preservation of public tranquility, and the absence of crime, will alone prove whether those efforts have been successful and whether the objects for which the police were appointed have been attained." [PARAGRAPH:1]In the early to mid-19th century Scotland Yard was the most advanced police force in the world. It gained worldwide notoriety from its pursuit of Jack the Ripper, and it was immortalized in the Sherlock Holmes stories of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. To this day the modern Scotland Yard remains one of the finest police forces to be found anywhere.
TEXT.Chinese: 苏格兰场是负责管辖大伦敦地区的英国警署。苏格兰场得名于早期警察总部所处的街区名，后来当总部搬迁（“新苏格兰场”）后他们仍然保留了这个昵称。[PARAGRAPH:1]苏格兰场于1829年根据参议院法案成立。根据一个新的警察委员所说：“警察机关的主要目标是预防犯罪行为的发生，其次是当罪案发生后搜捕并惩罚罪犯。总之，警察的所有努力如能产生如下效果：保护生命与财产，维护社会治安，消灭犯罪行为。就能证明我们的努力成功了，我们所赋予的目标实现了。”[PARAGRAPH:1]早在19世纪中叶，苏格兰场就是全世界最先进的警察部门。其名声由于对“开膛手杰克”的追捕而传遍全球，而柯南·道尔爵士笔下的福尔摩斯故事更令其名垂千古。今日的苏格兰场依然是这个星球上最好的警察部门之一。

TEXT.English: Built by the fourth dynasty of Egyptian rulers, the Pyramids represent the pinnacle of ancient Egyptian cultural achievement. Constructed on the Giza plateau outside modern-day Cairo, these structures were burial tombs and monuments for the Pharaohs, and may have taken generations and tens of thousands of workers to complete. The Pyramids are the only one of the generally accepted man-made wonders of the ancient world that remains in existence today.
TEXT.Chinese: 大金字塔，古埃及文化最杰出的代表作，由埃及第四王朝的统治者们建造。建筑地点位于今天的埃及首都开罗附近的吉萨高原。作为埃及法老的坟墓与纪念碑，金字塔的建造往往历尽数个朝代，并消耗成千上万的人力。埃及金字塔是仅有的仍然留存至今，并为世人所公认的古代世界建筑奇观之一。

TEXT.English: Stonehenge is perhaps the most astounding construct of pre-history still standing. Though standing in ruins, this mighty relic still has the power to insight amazement, awe and wonder. [PARAGRAPH:2]Stonehenge was built in southern England. Consisting of concentric circles of stone surrounded by a moat (called a "henge"), Stonehenge was constructed in several stages over thousands of years. The henge was dug approximately 5000 years ago; the inner ring of smaller "bluestones" were added about a thousand years later, in approximately 2000 BC; and the outer ring of huge sarsen stones was completed 500 years later. [PARAGRAPH:2]No one is sure exactly who constructed Stonehenge. For centuries it was romantically and erroneously believed that the Druids built the wonder, but in fact the edifice was completed 2000 years before there were any Druids. All we really know is that construction was begun by people of the Neolithic period and completed by those who supplanted them. [PARAGRAPH:2]Stonehenge is a wonder of engineering constructed with the most primitive tools. It appears that the outer ditch was dug with wooden and bone implements. The 80 inner bluestones, weighing about 4 tons each, were transported from a quarry over 240 miles away. Scientists speculate that the stones were dragged on logs and wooden sledges for part of the journey and carried on river barges for the rest. The heaviest of the outer ring of stones weighs in at about 50 tons; it took approximately 600 men to drag such stones from their quarry, about 20 miles away. These monster stones had to be pulled upright in exactly the correct position by men equipped with ropes and wooden levers. [PARAGRAPH:2]There is much debate about Stonehenge's purpose. Some theorize that it was built as a temple to honor earth gods, while others believe that it was a burial ground for ancient kings and noblemen. Another theory is that Stonehenge is an ancient astronomical observatory, charting the movement of the stars which men believed controlled their destinies.[PARAGRAPH:2]Whatever its original purpose, it remains today a rugged and beautiful monument to the astonishing skill and dedication of its "primitive" builders.
TEXT.Chinese: 巨石阵也许是遗存至今最令人感到神秘的史前建筑。虽然已经残破不堪，但是这个充满魔力的遗迹仍然令人陶醉不已。[PARAGRAPH:2]巨石阵位于英格兰南部。由圆石壕沟包围几圈巨大的同心圆石块组成，巨石阵的建造持续了数千年时间。外面的圆石壕沟大约在5000年前挖成；内环稍小的“胆矾石”约在公元前2000年时才加上；而外环的砂岩石又在此后500年才完工。[PARAGRAPH:2]没人知道究竟是谁建造了巨石阵。几个世纪以来，人们传说这是由德鲁伊教徒所建造的奇观，但事实上大致建筑在德鲁伊产生前2000年就已完工。我们所确知的一点只有：是新石器时代的人开始建造这个巨石阵，并由后来者最终完成的。[PARAGRAPH:2]对于原始的工具来说，巨石阵的确是一项工程奇迹。有迹象表明外层的壕沟是由木制和骨制的工具挖成的。80块内圈胆矾石，每块重约4吨，是从240英里外的采石场运来的。科学家推测这些石块是由原木撬和驳船运来的。外圈最重的石块有约50吨；大概要有600个人才能将它挖出来。这些巨型石块必须被竖立在正确的位置，而当时人们只有绳子和木制杠杆等原始工具。[PARAGRAPH:2]对于巨石阵的建造目的也有很大争议。有一个理论说这是供奉大地之神的庙宇，另有人相信这是古代王公贵族的陵墓。更有甚者说这是古代天文台，是那些相信星星的运动能控制自身命运的人用来制作星图的。[PARAGRAPH:2]但是无论当初原始目的为何，这个粗糙而美丽的纪念碑向我们揭示了原始人令人惊异的技术与奉献精神。

TEXT.English: The Great Library of Alexandria was one of the two most important libraries of the ancient world. Ptolemy I founded it around 300 BC, and was enhanced and expanded by his successors. The library attempted to obtain copies of all scrolls of any consequence, and eventually contained over 700,000 volumes. Religious fanatics destroyed the library in 391 AD, after nearly 700 years of operation. During this period, Alexandria served as the cultural center of the Hellenistic world. Today, only part of the catalog remains, providing us with a mere hint of what treasures the library contained.
TEXT.Chinese: 亚历山大图书馆是古代世界最重要的两座图书馆之一。由托勒密一世于公元前300年建造。并由其继任者不断扩充馆藏。馆中收集了超过70万卷的文化典籍。在其运作的700年间，亚历山大亦作为希腊世界的文化中心而为世人所景仰。但是在公元391年，一些宗教极端分子将其付之一炬。只剩一小部分书目流传至今，让人不禁猜测，当时这图书馆究竟拥有怎样的文化财富。

TEXT.English: The Pharos was a marble watchtower and lighthouse built in 280 BC on an island in the harbor of Alexandria, Egypt. Estimated to have been 300 feet high, the primary function of the lighthouse was to guide approaching ships to the harbor on an otherwise unmarked coast. Historians debate whether fires were burned on the top of the tower, or whether mirrors were used to reflect sunlight. Since ships rarely sailed along coasts at night, there was probably little need for the lighthouse after dark. The Pharos was destroyed in the 14th century, after having been damaged by several earthquakes.
TEXT.Chinese: 这是一座是全部由大理石建造的灯塔，同时也是一座了望塔。矗立在埃及亚历山大港口外的一个小岛上。其建成于公元前280年，约有300英尺高。用来指引来自其他地方的船只进入亚历山大港。历史学家一直在争论，灯塔到底是用火还是镜子来照明，因为当时很少有船只在晚上航行。在经历了几次地震后，灯塔于14世纪倒塌。

TEXT.English: The Hanging Gardens were a distinctive feature of ancient Babylon. They were a great source of pride to the people, and were often described in accounts written by visitors to the city. Possibly built by King Nebuchadnezzar II in 600 BC, the gardens are believed to have been a remarkable feat of engineering: an ascending series of tiered gardens containing all manner of trees, shrubs, and vines. The gardens were said to have looked like a large green mountain constructed of mud bricks, rising from the center of the city.
TEXT.Chinese: 空中花园作为古巴比伦的独特建筑之一，令当地的人民为之深深自豪。并且经常出现在那些到访这城市的旅行者的笔下。它可能是由尼布甲尼撒二世于公元前600年建造。它具有无可比拟的工程设计，由一系列建筑在台阶上的花园组成，其上覆满了各种树木，灌木和蔓生植物。以至于从远处看去，像一座矗立在城市中央的巨大的砖制绿色山丘。

TEXT.English: The Colossus of Rhodes was a bronze statue of Helios, the Greek God of the Sun, erected near the mouth of the city harbor. It stood over 100 feet high, about two-thirds the height of the Statue of Liberty. Unfortunately, an earthquake toppled it only 56 years after its construction. Taking the counsel of an oracle, the city elected to leave the statue where it lay. For over 900 years, people from all over the ancient world came to Rhodes to see the Colossus. It remained where it was until 654 AD when the Muslims who plundered the city sold the statue for scrap.
TEXT.Chinese: 罗德岛的巨像是希腊太阳神赫利俄斯的青铜铸像，矗立在城市海港的入口处。他的高度超过一百英尺，大约是自由女神像的三分之二。不幸的是，他在建成后的第56个年头，因地震而倒塌。市民们依照一个神谕的指示，将这伟大建筑的遗迹保留在原地。其后的九百年间，络绎不绝的访客由世界各地前来观赏这青铜巨像的遗迹。直到公元645年，入侵的穆斯林劫掠了这座城市，并将遗留的巨像残片变卖。

TEXT.English: In ancient Greek religion, an oracle was a priest or priestess through whom the gods spoke in response to questions. The oracle interpreted dreams, the actions of entranced persons, and physical signs found in the entrails of sacrificed animals. The most famous oracle resided in the shrine of Apollo at Delphi, located on the slopes of Mount Parnassus. Greeks, Romans, and others consulted this oracle for centuries about public policy and private matters. A priestess called the Pythia would, for a fee, make public predictions for the future. These ecstatic pronouncements became infamous for their ambiguity.
TEXT.Chinese: 在古希腊的信仰中，“先知”是指那些为人们传达诸神意旨的女祭司。先知负责解读梦境，着魔者的行为，以及作为祭品的动物内脏上的纹理所包含的神灵谕示。宣示神谕的先知驻所中最著名的一个是位于希腊古城特尔斐帕那萨斯山的阿波罗神殿。古希腊、古罗马和其他国家的人们时时来访，以决定从公共政策到私人事务的各种各样的问题。一个名叫派西亚的女祭司则为他们宣示关于未来的预言并收取一定费用。这些神谕最大的特点就是用词含混不清，模棱两可。

TEXT.English: The Parthenon was constructed in 433 BC, in Athens, Greece, in honor of Athens' patron goddess, Athena. Measuring 100 feet by 225 feet, the Parthenon is constructed almost totally of marble. The exterior of the Parthenon is ringed with Doric-style columns more than 30 feet in height, and the center part of the temple, called the "cella," is a large open space which once held a statue of Athena. Much of the temple was decorated with beautiful marble statues and friezes celebrating Athena and the glories of Athens. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Parthenon has suffered much from the ravages of time. In the 5th century a Roman Emperor stole the statue of Athena and moved it to Constantinople, where it was subsequently destroyed. In the 13th century the Parthenon was converted to a Catholic church, which involved altering the internal structure and removing (and probably destroying) many statues dedicated to the old gods. In the 15th century Athens was captured by the Ottomans, and the temple was turned into a mosque. In the 17th century the Parthenon was partially destroyed during a war between the Ottomans and Venetians. Finally, in the 19th century, the British ambassador to Greece looted all of the surviving marble friezes from the building, which he subsequently sold to the British museum. [PARAGRAPH:2]Despite the centuries of neglect, mutilation and pillaging, the Parthenon still stands - a remarkably powerful and beautiful symbol of the glories of ancient Greece.
TEXT.Chinese: 位于希腊雅典的帕特农神庙修建于公元前433年，用于祭祀雅典的守护神——雅典娜。神庙长225英尺，宽100英尺，几乎全部为大理石构成。神庙四周以30余英尺高的多利安式圆柱围绕，内部则是一开阔空间，曾一度矗立着一尊雅典娜女神的塑像。神庙用精美的大理石雕像，檐壁和中楣装饰赞美雅典娜和雅典的荣耀。[PARAGRAPH:2]帕特农神庙在历史上屡遭劫难。公元5世纪时，罗马皇帝盗走了雅典娜神像，神像被搬运至君士坦丁堡，后来毁于该处。13世纪时，帕特农神庙被改建成天主教堂，这导致了内部结构的改变，而许多描绘原始信仰神祗的雕像也被移走或被破坏。雅典在15世纪被奥斯曼土耳其人征服，神庙也变作了清真寺。17世纪土耳其和威尼斯之间的战争使神庙部分被毁。最后在19世纪，英国驻希腊的大使窃走了幸存的所有大理石雕塑，并出售给大英博物馆。[PARAGRAPH:2]尽管经历了数世纪的疏于管理，毁损和掠夺，帕特农神庙依然矗立至今，成为古希腊光辉历史的美丽象征。

TEXT.English: Angkor Wat is a temple in Angkor, Cambodia. Angkor Wat was constructed in the 12th century by King Suryavaman II to serve as the royal palace and state temple, Hinduism being the state religion. Two or three centuries later Angkor Wat was converted to Buddhist use. Angkor Wat is a complex of buildings surrounded by a wall and then moat. The enclosed area measures 3000 feet by 2600 feet. [PARAGRAPH:2]Angkor Wat is constructed primarily of sandstone blocks. The complex is laid out in a rectangular pattern somewhat resembling that of an ancient fortress; the inner buildings are separated from the outer walls by a courtyard similar to a bailey one might find in a castle. [PARAGRAPH:2]At one time the courtyard was filled with wooden buildings, but these have all since perished. The inner structure is split into three galleries built on raised platforms. The outer galleys once contained libraries, while the inner was a shrine to Vishnu (and has since been converted to a shrine to Buddha). The galleries are topped with towers that resemble stylized beehives, the tallest reaching about 140 feet in height. The buildings' walls are covered with ornate and beautiful bas relief sculptures depicting scenes from Hindu mythology. [PARAGRAPH:2]Though largely neglected in the latter half of the 20th century, serious efforts are now being made to preserve and restore this wonderful and unique place of worship, and pilgrims and tourists are visiting it in ever-greater numbers each year.
TEXT.Chinese: 吴哥窟是位于柬埔寨吴哥地区的一座寺庙，由12世纪时的高棉国王苏利亚瓦尔曼二世修建。它是一座王宫，同时也是一座印度教寺院。2到3个世纪后，吴哥窟又改建成一座佛教寺院。吴哥窟是由城墙和护城河围绕的一组建筑群，其范围大约3000英尺长，2600英尺宽。[PARAGRAPH:2]吴哥窟大部由砂岩筑成。整个建筑群呈矩形，犹如古代堡垒；内部建筑与外墙之间有城堡外庭一般的庭院隔开。[PARAGRAPH:2]庭院里全是木构建筑，但如今已经全部朽坏。修建于凸起平台之上的内部结构可以分为三个回廊。外部的回廊曾包括图书馆，而内部回廊则是一座毗湿奴神殿（后来改为佛堂）。建筑的顶部是类似蜂巢般规整结构的佛塔，其中最高的大概有140英尺。建筑群的外墙上满是精美的浮雕，这些浮雕讲述的是印度神话里的故事。[PARAGRAPH:2]在20世纪后半叶的大多数时间中，这里被人们所忽视。但是现在，人们正努力保护并复原这一历史奇观和独一无二的圣地，而每年造访此地的朝圣者和游客也越来越多。

TEXT.English: The Hagia Sophia, or "Church of the Holy Wisdom," was constructed in 530 AD as a Greek Orthodox church. Standing in Istanbul (originally Constantinople), Turkey, it is a beautiful and ornate structure, built of stone and marble, and topped by a golden dome measuring over 100 feet in diameter. An extremely difficult engineering challenge for the time, the dome has collapsed several times during its existence. Four graceful towers stand at the corners of the building. [PARAGRAPH:2]The interior of the Hagia Sophia is a marvelous space of columns and arches extending up to the dome, which appears almost to float atop the building. The interior was sheathed in colored marble and golden mosaics depicting biblical scenes and images of Christian saints. [PARAGRAPH:2]In 1453 Constantinople was captured by the Ottoman Turks, and the Hagia Sophia was converted into a mosque. Human images are not welcome in mosques, and many of the mosaics were covered with plaster. [PARAGRAPH:2]In 1934, Turkish President Kemal Ataturk turned the building into a museum. In recent years some restoration work has been done on the Hagia Sophia, and a few of the mosaics have been uncovered. Despite the ravages of time, the Hagia Sophia remains universally acknowledged as one of the most beautiful buildings in the world.
TEXT.Chinese: 圣索菲亚大教堂，又名“圣智大教堂”，是一座修建于公元530年的希腊东正教教堂，位于土耳其伊斯坦布尔（君士坦丁堡）。圣索菲亚大教堂是一座华美的建筑，由大理石和花岗石建成，拥有一个直径超过100英尺的金色圆顶。修建这个圆顶在当时是一项极其困难的工程，历史上这个圆顶曾经坍塌过数次。在教堂的四角各有一座优美的高塔矗立。[PARAGRAPH:2]建筑的内部是由延伸至穹顶的柱廊和拱形结构组成的奇妙空间，这些结构使得教堂的穹顶仿佛没有基座，而是悬浮在空中一般。建筑的内墙上满是由彩色大理石和玻璃镶嵌画描述的圣经中的场景与基督教圣人的形象。[PARAGRAPH:2]1453年，君士坦丁堡被土耳其人攻占，圣索菲亚大教堂也被改建成清真寺。由于清真寺内禁止人物画像，许多镶嵌画被用灰浆覆盖。[PARAGRAPH:2]1934年，土耳其总统，国父凯末尔将清真寺改为博物馆。近年来，人们对圣索菲亚进行了复原工作，一些被灰浆掩盖的镶嵌画得以重见天日。尽管时间流逝，圣索菲亚仍以世界上最美丽的建筑之一而闻名于世。

TEXT.English: Chichen Itza is an extraordinary city of stone built in the Yucatan, Mexico. Some of the oldest buildings and pyramids date back to 1500 years ago and are of Toltec and Mayan origin. [PARAGRAPH:2]Chichen Itza consists of buildings, temples and courtyards of stone. A large "pok tap ok" or ceremonial ball court stands off to one side. (Ceremonial ball is that most interesting of games in which two sides seek to pass the ball through hoops at each end of the court. The captain of the winning team was then beheaded as a sacrifice to the gods.) Though the city is much ravaged by time (and looters), there still remain many beautiful stone carvings and statues. [PARAGRAPH:2]At the center of the city stands the mighty stepped pyramid of Kukulcan, also known as "El Castillo." Constructed around the 13th century, El Castillo is approximately 180 feet square at the base and 78 feet in height. As was the Mayan practice, Kukulcan was constructed atop an older and smaller pyramid. [PARAGRAPH:2]Chichen Itza was a thriving city until the 13th century, when revolt and civil war broke out among the Mayans, at which point the city went into a steep decline from which it never recovered. The center of the city was largely abandoned and in ruins by the time of the Spanish Conquest of the Yucatan in the 16th century.
TEXT.Chinese: 奇琴伊察是建造在墨西哥尤卡坦的一座非凡的石头城。其中的一些最古老的建筑和金字塔可以追溯到1500年前，由托尔泰克人和玛雅人建造。[PARAGRAPH:2]奇琴伊察由石制建筑，寺庙和庭院构成。一个巨大的仪式舞蹈场地座落在城市的一端。（仪式舞蹈是一种非常令人好奇的游戏，两支队伍需要尝试把球踢过场地两端的铁环。之后，获胜队伍的队长会作为给神的祭品而砍头。）尽管这座城市历史上遭到了时间和掠夺者的破坏，仍然有不少漂亮的石头雕像存留。[PARAGRAPH:2]在城市中央矗立着宏大的库库尔坎的金字塔，西班牙人称之为“城堡”。它建造于13世纪，占地面积大约为180平方英尺，高达78英尺。根据玛雅的惯例，库库尔坎建立在一个更古老并稍小的金字塔之上。[PARAGRAPH:2]直到13世纪，奇琴伊察都是一个繁荣的城市。此后，玛雅爆发了叛乱和内战，导致了这座城市的迅速没落，并再也没有恢复。到西班牙人在16世纪征服尤卡坦的时候，城市中心已经被很大程度地遗弃而成为了废墟。

TEXT.English: The beauty of Rome's Sistine Chapel has long served as a testament to the mixture of strong religious beliefs and the love of art shared by the people of Renaissance Europe. Michelangelo devoted four years to painting the mural that adorns the ceiling, a work depicting events in the book of Genesis and other Biblical stories. Few visitors to the Sistine Chapel have failed to be moved by the artist's dedication to his subject, or his feeling for the nature of human struggle, suffering, and spiritual triumph.
TEXT.Chinese: 罗马西斯廷大教堂作为文艺复兴时期的标志性建筑之一，集中体现了那个时代人们对宗教和对艺术的热爱。由米开朗基罗耗费四年时间绘制的穹顶壁画，描绘了创世纪中的记载及其他圣经故事。所有参观这座大教堂的人，几乎无一不为艺术家的创作热情及其作品中所表达的人类的抗争，苦难以及灵魂的胜利所倾倒。

TEXT.English: The Spiral Minaret is a massive brick and clay structure adjacent to the Mosque of al-Mutawakkil in Samarra, Iraq. The mosque was constructed in 852 AD, and at the time was the largest mosque in the world.[PARAGRAPH:2]A remarkable triumph of ancient engineering, the minaret is a circular tower 170 feet in height. A spiral exterior staircase extends up the tower to the platform where the "muezzin" called the people to prayer. It is said that the caliph al-Mutawakkil once rode up the stairs on a white Egyptian donkey. [PARAGRAPH:2]An imposing yet magnificent building, the Spiral Minaret still stands today, calling the people of Samarra to prayer at the Mosque of al-Mutawakkil. The more courageous visitors can climb the staircase to the top of the minaret, which appears to lack an outside guardrail.
TEXT.Chinese: 螺旋尖塔是伊拉克撒马拉的穆塔瓦基勒清真寺边上的一个砖土结构建筑物。这座清真寺建造于公元852年，是当时世界上最大的清真寺。[PARAGRAPH:2]螺旋尖塔是一座圆形的170英尺高的塔，它是古代工程学的一个奇迹。有一座螺旋状的外部阶梯从塔上延伸到一个平台，这是宣礼员通告人们进行祷告的地方。据说哈里发穆塔瓦基勒曾经骑着一匹白色埃及驴登上阶梯。[PARAGRAPH:2]作为一座令人难忘的宏伟建筑，螺旋尖塔至今仍然矗立，呼唤撒马拉的人们前往穆塔瓦基勒清真寺祈祷。如果访客足够大胆，他还可以通过阶梯登上没有任何护栏的尖塔的顶部。

TEXT.English: Notre Dame is a mighty cathedral standing on the "Ile de la Citie," an island in the Seine River in Paris, France. Built on the site of an older church, which was in turn built on the site of a Roman temple to Jupiter, Notre Dame is a magnificent example of gothic architecture and one of the greatest buildings standing. Construction of Notre Dame began in 1163 and took almost two centuries to complete. [PARAGRAPH:2]Notre Dame is a massive stone building of square towers, flying buttresses, and tall spires. The exterior of the building is decorated with delicate ribbons of arches and statues of saints and kings. The roofline of the building is festooned with gargoyles. The interior of the cathedral is a long, narrow space with columns lining each side, supporting two beautiful raised galleries. Brilliant stained glass windows shine gently down on the main altar, which contains a beautiful statue of the Virgin Mary, the cathedral's patron, holding the body of Jesus. [PARAGRAPH:2]The cathedral has suffered many periods of neglect over the years. During the French Revolution, many of Notre Dame's treasures were stolen and the building was used as a warehouse. In the early 1800s, the cathedral was in such a state of disrepair that the city planners contemplated tearing it down. In fact, Victor Hugo wrote "The Hunchback of Notre Dame" in part to raise awareness of the cathedral's plight. In 1871, during the short-lived Paris Commune, Notre Dame was almost set on fire. [PARAGRAPH:2]Fortunately the cathedral survived it all, and has now been largely restored to its original grandeur.
TEXT.Chinese: 圣母院是座落于法国巴黎塞纳河上的“城市岛”上的一座宏伟的大教堂。它的原址是一座由罗马的朱庇特神庙改建的古老教堂。巴黎圣母院是一座典型的哥特式建筑，也是世界上仍存在的最伟大的建筑之一。圣母院的建造从1163年开始，前后将近用了200年才完成。[PARAGRAPH:2]圣母院是一座石质建筑，由许多的方塔，飞拱和高耸的尖顶组成。其外表装饰有许多拱形带和圣徒们与国王们的雕像，屋顶的轮廓饰有怪兽状的滴水口。大教堂的内部是一个又长又窄的空间，四周的圆柱支撑着两幅漂亮的浮雕。彩色玻璃窗轻轻地照耀在主祭坛上，在这个祭坛上有一座圣母玛丽的雕像，她的怀中则抱着耶稣——这座大教堂由此得名。[PARAGRAPH:2]这座大教堂在历史上遭遇过多次劫难。在法国大革命时代，圣母院中的许多财产被窃，并被征用为仓库。在19世纪初，这座大教堂的荒废景象使得城市的规划者考虑将它拆除。事实上，维克多·雨果撰写《巴黎圣母院》的部分目的就是希望唤起人们对圣母院的困境的关注。在1871年，在短命的巴黎公社执政期间，圣母院几乎被焚毁。[PARAGRAPH:2]幸运的是，圣母院从这一系列的遭难中幸存下来，现在已经基本上恢复了原有的宏伟。

TEXT.English: The Taj Mahal stands in Agra, India. It was constructed in the mid-16th century at the orders of the Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan, as a mausoleum for his wife. [PARAGRAPH:2]Acknowledged as one of the most beautiful structures in the world, the Taj Mahal is constructed of rare and brilliant materials imported from across India and Asia - it is said that over 1000 elephants were employed to carry the sandstone, marble, jade, turquoise, sapphires, and other materials used in its construction. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Taj Mahal complex covers an area of approximately 1000 feet by 1900 feet and consists of a gateway, garden, mausoleum, mosque, and guest house. The first three buildings are clad in white marble and covered with geometric patterns, while the mosque and guesthouse are built of brilliant red sandstone. The buildings are topped with magnificent onion-shaped domes and minarets. [PARAGRAPH:2]Experts have debated about what makes the Taj Mahal unique and beautiful. Some suggest that it lies in the structures' marvelous proportions and symmetry, while others argue in favor of the way that the marble buildings interact with the light, giving the Taj Mahal ever-changing character as the sun rises and sets. Still others believe that its inherent beauty lies in its purpose - a man seeking to cast in stone his love for his departed wife.
TEXT.Chinese: 泰姬陵位于印度阿格拉。它是在16世纪中叶，依照莫卧儿帝国皇帝沙贾罕的命令而建造，作为其妻子的陵墓。[PARAGRAPH:2]泰姬陵被公认为世界上最漂亮的建筑物之一，它使用从印度和亚洲进口的各种稀有而美丽的材料建造而成。据说人们使用了1000头大象来搬运这些砂岩，大理石，翡翠，绿宝石，蓝宝石和其他的材料。[PARAGRAPH:2]泰姬陵总共占据了大约宽1000英尺，长1900英尺的广阔面积，包括一座大门，一个大花园，陵墓，一座清真寺和客房。前三个建筑覆盖着白色大理石并装饰着几何图形，而清真寺与客房在使用闪亮的红色砂岩建造。这些建筑顶部是洋葱状的圆顶和尖塔。[PARAGRAPH:2]专家们曾就泰姬陵独特和美丽的原因展开争论。一些认为这源自其不可思议的精确比例和对称，而另一些则倾向于大理石建筑在光线下的相互间的影响，这使得泰姬陵在太阳升起与落下时呈现出不断变化的景象。还有一些人相信它的美丽源于其建造的初衷：一个男人想要把他对亡妻的爱浇筑在石头中。

TEXT.English: "Kremlin" is a Russian word which denotes a fortified complex of buildings in the center of a city. It is most often used to refer to the Kremlin in the city of Moscow, a remarkable set of buildings which hold much of the Russian government. The Kremlin sits on a hill overlooking the Moskva River. In one form or the other, fortified structures have been in that location for almost 1000 years. The site was named "Kremlin" in the 14th century. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Kremlin is within a triangular, walled area about 68 acres in extent. The walls are of red brick, with pencil-like towers at the corners and entrances. Many of the buildings are painted white with yellow trim and green roofs that look quite cheerful from a distance. The Cathedral of the Dormition, constructed in the 1470s, is the oldest building in the complex. Two other cathedrals lie within its walls, as do a surprising number of palaces, the Kremlin Palace being the largest.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Kremlin has seen many great figures rise and fall within its walls. Ivan the Terrible built the Palace of Facets in the Kremlin. In the Great Patriotic War (WWII), Josef Stalin drove the German invaders from the gates of Moscow - perhaps the greatest service that any Russian ruler has ever performed for his country. (It was also here that Stalin planned the systematic extermination of millions of his own people.) It was here that Mikhail Gorbachev oversaw the dissolution of the Soviet Union. Today, the Kremlin holds the government of the Russian Federation.[PARAGRAPH:2]To whatever use it might be put in the future, the Kremlin will always stand as a mighty monument to Russia's past - for it has seen the best and the worst of that great nation.
TEXT.Chinese: “克里姆林”是一个俄语词，它表示在城市中心的一组防御建筑群，特别指在莫斯科市中心的“克里姆林”，作为城市标志性建筑群，是绝大多数的俄罗斯政府机构的所在地。克里姆林位于可以俯瞰莫斯科河的山丘上。在这个地点，各种形式的防御建筑已经存在了近1000年。但直到14世纪时才被命名为克里姆林。[PARAGRAPH:2]克里姆林宫建筑平面图呈现一个三角形，以城墙围绕，面积将近68英亩。墙壁用红色砖块砌成，在转角和入口有像铅笔般高耸的哨塔。其中许多建筑被漆成黄檐绿顶，看上去非常的喜庆。圣母升天大教堂建于15世纪70年代，是整个建筑群中历史最悠久的。城墙内还另有两座大教堂。而“大克里姆林宫”则是城墙内众多宫殿建筑中最大的一座。[PARAGRAPH:2]许多大人物在克里姆林的围墙内沉浮。伊凡雷帝在克里姆林建造了菲赛特宫。在苏联卫国战争（第二次世界大战）中，约瑟夫·斯大林在莫斯科城下击退了德国侵略军，他这项功绩的辉煌程度超越了所有其他的俄国统治者。（但也是在这个地方，斯大林制订了杀害了上百万自己同胞的计划。）在这里，戈尔巴乔夫目睹了苏联的解体。今天，克里姆林宫仍旧是俄罗斯政府的所在地。[PARAGRAPH:2]无论克里姆林宫在将来会作什么用途，它仍会永远地象征俄罗斯的过去，因为这个国家所有最糟和最好的事件都发生在这里。

TEXT.English: The Eiffel Tower is one of the world's most famous landmarks. Built for the Universal Exposition of 1889, the tower rises 984 feet above Paris' Champ de Mars, near the Seine River. Structural engineer Alexandre Gustave Eiffel built the tower at a cost of more than $1 million to demonstrate how steel and iron could be utilized in the construction of extremely tall buildings. The tallest building in the world when it was originally completed, the Eiffel Tower drew crowds of awestruck observers from around the world. Today, it remains one of Paris' leading tourist attractions.
TEXT.Chinese: 埃菲尔铁塔是世界上最著名的地标之一。它屹立在塞纳河畔的战神广场，高984英尺。为了1889年的世界博览会，结构工程师埃菲尔花费了一百多万美元建造了这座铁塔，以展示钢与铁是如何在极高的建筑结构中使用。当时它是世界最高的建筑物，吸引了成群结队从世界各地慕名而来的瞻仰者。今天，它仍旧是巴黎最吸引人的景点之一。

TEXT.English: The Statue of Liberty is one of the largest statues in the world. Measuring over 300 feet tall from the base of its pedestal, the statue is constructed of copper plating over an iron framework and weighs over 250 metric tons. Designed by French sculptor Frederic Bartholdi, the statue, with her upraised torch and the broken chains of tyranny at her feet, was presented to the United States by the French government in 1886 to commemorate 100 years of American independence. The statue itself, Liberty Island, and nearby Ellis Island became a national monument in 1924. For more than a century, the Statue of Liberty has stood at the mouth of the New York harbor. Often the first sight seen by immigrants arriving in America, Lady Liberty symbolizes the ideals of freedom upon which the United States was founded.
TEXT.Chinese: 自由女神像是世界上最大的雕像之一。连基座高达300多英尺。她建造在镀铜的铁框架上，总重量达250吨。这座雕像由法国著名雕塑家巴尔托迪设计，造型为自由女神高举火炬，脚上还残留着断裂的苛政的铁锁，是法国政府为纪念1886年美国独立100周年而赠送的礼物。1924年，雕塑本身，自由岛，以及附近的艾丽丝岛被宣布为国家历史文物。自由女神像已经在纽约港的河口屹立了一个多世纪。每一个来到美国的移民首先看到的就是自由女神像，它象征了自由的理念，这是美国建国的基础。

TEXT.English: Broadway is the name of a wide street that cuts through the center of New York City, New York. It has also come to refer to the New York theatre district which straddles Broadway near Times Square in the middle of the city. Over the years, approximately 200 theatres have been built on or around Broadway, some going on to spectacular success, others failing within months. [PARAGRAPH:2]The first recorded professional theatrical performance held in New York occurred in 1732. The play was a comedy titled "The Recruiting Officer." The play was performed in an improvised space; unfortunately, the exact location of the performance has been lost. New York's first known theatre was opened in 1750; the Theatre on Nassau Street held about 280 people. The theatre lasted about four years before being torn down and replaced by a church. [PARAGRAPH:2]At present there are over forty theatres in operation. These theatres offer a selection of dramas, comedies and musicals, with musicals being in vogue at present. The competition is extremely tough, and many shows fail within weeks of opening. Clearly, Broadway is one of the two centers of American performance arts - with Hollywood, of course, being the other.
TEXT.Chinese: 百老汇是贯穿纽约市中心的一条大街的名字。同时它也指纽约市中心时代广场附近的剧院区，百老汇就穿过了该区。许多年来，近200家剧院在百老汇或者附近建造，有些大获成功，有些则在几个月内倒闭。[PARAGRAPH:2]纽约第一次有记录的专业戏剧演出是在1732年，是一部名叫“征兵官”的喜剧。演出在临时搭建的舞台上进行，可惜确切的地点已经无从考证。纽约已知的第一家剧场在1750年开张，该剧场坐落于拿骚街，能够容纳280人左右。四年之后该剧场倒闭，被一座教堂替代。[PARAGRAPH:2]百老汇现在有40多家剧场还在运作。这些剧场上演各种舞台剧，喜剧和音乐剧等，而音乐剧是目前最为流行的。剧场的竞争非常的激烈，其中很多在开张几周内就关门大吉。百老汇是美国两大表演艺术中心之一，当然另一处则是好莱坞。

TEXT.English: Elvis Presley, "The King", played a new beat that people called Rock-n-Roll. It quickly became a worldwide sensation. Elvis' home was called "Graceland" and was purchased by Presley in 1957. Presley died in 1977; the 14-acre estate was turned into a museum five years later. Presley, his parents, grandmother, and stillborn twin brother are buried on the grounds. [PARAGRAPH:2]Today Graceland stands as a remarkable testament to a man who achieved almost mythological status in American culture. Therein one can see glimpses of the young Elvis - the brilliant jeans-clad rebel who "sang like a black man," the man who seduced American teens from the clutches of British rockers and frightened parents everywhere. [PARAGRAPH:2]Overlaying these faint images is the picture of what Elvis became: the jaded overweight man, singing in Las Vegas in a white sequined jumpsuit, dodging underwear thrown by middle-aged housewives, shaking hands with Richard Nixon, and finally dying of his excesses. [PARAGRAPH:2]Today, Elvis is still beloved by millions, many of whom refuse to believe that he died. Despite this, they flock to the mansion by the thousands to lay flowers at his gravesite.
TEXT.Chinese: 艾尔维斯·普莱斯利，人称“猫王”，他开创了一种新的音乐形式——摇滚。它很快成为一种世界性的娱乐方式。普莱斯利于1957年购置的居所也人被称为“恩赐之地”。普莱斯利于1977年去世，5年之后，这片14英亩的土地被改建为一座纪念馆。普莱斯利，他的父母，祖母和他刚出生即死亡的双胞胎兄弟都葬在这里。[PARAGRAPH:2]今天，恩赐之地已经成为一份值得纪念的遗产，它属于一个在美国文化史上几乎拥有神话般的地位的人。今天在那里你可以看到年轻时代的艾尔维斯——穿着闪亮的夹克的叛逆者，“像个黑人似地歌唱”。这个人深深地吸引了那些喜欢英国摇滚乐的美国青少年们，也使得无数的家长们深感不安。[PARAGRAPH:2]许多艾尔维斯的照片在唤醒人们对他过去的回忆：疲惫不堪，略显发胖的男子，穿着闪闪发光的白色跳舞服在拉斯维加斯唱歌，不停地躲避着那些中年主妇们扔过来的内衣，与尼克松总统握手，最终他死于放纵无度的生活。[PARAGRAPH:2]今天，仍然有成千上万的人依然热爱着他，许多人拒绝相信他已经死去。还有无数人涌到这里，在他的墓碑前留下鲜花。

TEXT.English: Hollywood is a neighborhood in Los Angeles, California. Hollywood is also the center of the American film industry, making it perhaps the most potent center of cultural influence seen since Paris dominated the world of fashion, arts, and literature in the 18th and 19th centuries. Hollywood owes its existence to two important features: first, the weather is mild and pleasant for most of the year; and second, because of its distance from New Jersey. [PARAGRAPH:2]New Jersey was the first film center in the United States, owing to the simple fact that Thomas Edison lived in New Jersey and he held many patents regarding the new technology. He and other early film producers formed a powerful monopoly on the East Coast, where they spent much time and effort trying to stamp out the many small independent producers. To evade Edison and his lawyers, a number of these businesses relocated to Hollywood, Los Angeles, where they were to shortly put Edison and his cronies out of business. [PARAGRAPH:2]The period of 1927 to 1948 was the "Golden Age of Hollywood." Five major studios dominated the industry. The studios created the "star system," in which they heavily promoted their actors and actresses, making them household names while keeping them in ironclad contracts. The system was eventually broken when the actors began refusing to sign the contracts and instead created their own production companies. During this period Hollywood produced hundreds of movies, some-of which were great, many more of which were mediocre or worse. [PARAGRAPH:2]While Hollywood has diminished somewhat in power and influence, it is still home to many of the major motion picture and television production companies, and it still remains a strong exporter of American culture the world wide.
TEXT.Chinese: 好莱坞是加利福尼亚州洛杉矶市的一个社区，也是美国电影工业的中心。这使其成为几乎最强有力的文化中心，正如巴黎在18世纪和19世纪牢牢地统治着世界的时尚，艺术和文学潮流。好莱坞的成功应归功于两个重要因素：首先，全年的大部分时候气候都温和宜人，其次，因为这里远离新泽西。[PARAGRAPH:2]新泽西是美国的第一个电影工业中心，这只是因为托马斯·爱迪生住在新泽西，他拥有许多与这项新科技有关的专利。他和其他早期电影制片商在东海岸形成了强大的垄断集团，他们花费了大量的时间和精力来压制那些中小的独立制片商。为了躲避爱迪生和他的律师们，这些商人们选择了洛杉矶的好莱坞，在那里他们很快摆脱了爱迪生和他的那些亲信们。[PARAGRAPH:2]1927到1948年是好莱坞的黄金时期。五大主要制片商控制了这一产业。他们创立了明星体制，大力地提拔他们的男女演员，使他们家喻户晓，同时又用合同牢牢地控制着他们。这一制度最终被演员们打破，他们拒绝签这种合同，代以成立自己的制作公司。这一时期好莱坞制作了成百上千的电影，有些是伟大的杰作，但更多的只是平庸或更糟的作品。[PARAGRAPH:2]尽管好莱坞的影响力和权利在某种程度上已经削弱，它仍然是许多大电影制片商和电视出品公司的根据地，它仍然是向全世界出口美国文化的强大力量。

TEXT.English: The Three Gorges Dam project is designed to tap the power of the mighty Yangtze River, the third longest river in the world. Construction began in Hubei Province, China, in 1994, and it is scheduled to be completed in 2009. When complete, it will be 600 feet high and run 1.3 miles, making it the largest hydroelectric dam in the world. The Chinese government estimates the final cost to be $30 billion dollars, while independent estimates put the cost at closer to $75 billion. [PARAGRAPH:2]Constructing a dam on the Yangtze was proposed as far back as 1919 by Sun Yat-sen, but the idea was shelved for 40 years due to a series of wars, revolutions, and other national calamities hitting China. The idea was resurrected in 1954, abandoned, resurrected again in 1963, abandoned, and so on until it was given final approval in 1992. [PARAGRAPH:2]There has been much debate over the project, primarily because it will dislocate almost two million people, but also because of its potentially devastating environmental impact and because it will eradicate 1300 archeological sites in the area. The Chinese government has pushed the project forward despite these objections and despite the unprecedented opposition of over 30%% of the delegates to the National People's Congress, a body which usually rubber-stamps government decisions.
TEXT.Chinese: 三峡大坝是一项利用长江丰富的水利资源的大型工程，长江是世界第三长河。工程建设开始于1994年，在中国的湖北省，设计竣工时间为2009年。预计在完工后，大坝将有600英尺高，1.3英里长，是世界上最大的水电大坝。中国政府估计最终投资达到300亿美元，中立方则估计投资将达到750亿美元之巨。[PARAGRAPH:2]在长江上建水坝的构想可追溯到1919年的孙中山，但这一设想被中国面临的一系列的战争，革命以及各种自然灾害耽搁了40年。这一计划于1954年曾经被提起又放弃，1963年又再度被提起又再度被放弃，直到这一计划最终于1992年被确定。[PARAGRAPH:2]对这一计划存在着很多争议，首先是这将要迁移大约两百万人，而后是将淹没1300处该地区的重要古迹。尽管存在诸多争议，中国政府还是决定实施这一计划，三峡工程项目在全国人民代表大会表决时竟出现超过30%%的反对意见，对这个向来被视为政府决策“橡皮图章”的机构来说可谓空前。

TEXT.English: The Pentagon is the largest office building in existence. The structure was completed on January 15, 1943, during the height of the Second World War, after a crash building effort of only 16 months. The 83 million dollar facility covers more than six million square feet, roughly three times that of the Chicago's Sears Tower (the second largest office building). Originally a US Army facility, it soon became the nerve center for all military branches of the United States.
TEXT.Chinese: 五角大楼是现存最大的办公建筑。它建成于1943年1月15日，第二次世界大战最激烈的时刻。这座耗资8300万美元的建筑占地600万平方英尺。是芝加哥西尔斯塔楼（第二大办公建筑）的三倍。起初是美国陆军的设施，但很快它就成了整个美国军队的神经中枢。

TEXT.English: Created in 1945 to maintain international peace and security, the United Nations was the second of two laudable efforts to establish an international authority on law and human rights between the self governing nations of the world. Headquartered in New York City, the United Nations was established at the end of World War II in response to the apparent ineffectiveness of the League of Nations to prevent another global conflict on the scale of "The War to End All Wars".[PARAGRAPH:2]The UN was originally conceived in 1941 as the Atlantic Charter, an agreement signed between Winston Churchill and Franklin D. Roosevelt, but developed into a pact signed by 26 countries to try to stop the aggression of the Axis powers. In 1945, in a conference between "The Big Three", Churchill, Roosevelt, and Stalin, the original charter was laid down.[PARAGRAPH:2]Throughout its history the United Nations has had great success in establishing many permanent international laws on subjects from human rights, international treaties, and worldwide decolonization. Although the United Nations does not have the power to enforce decisions or compel nations to take military action, the ability to compel member nations to impose economic sanctions against countries guilty of violating security orders gives it significant power in the world stage.
TEXT.Chinese: 1945年成立的联合国是历史上第二个以协调各独立国家间关系，保证国际法律的权威性和人权为目标的权力机构。其总部位于纽约市。联合国成立于二战末期，部分由于之前的国际联盟在二战中所表现的低效率和无力性，目的是防止可能导致人类毁灭的战争爆发。[PARAGRAPH:2]联合国的最初构思源于温斯顿·丘吉尔，富兰克林·罗斯福于1941年发表的大西洋宪章，并随着26国间签署的试图结束轴心国的侵略战争的条约而得以进一步实现。并最终于1945年的“三巨头”丘吉尔，罗斯福，斯大林的会面中签署了基础协议。[PARAGRAPH:2]在其组建后，联合国成功地通过了一批永久性国际公约，在保护人权，确定国际谈判规章，推进全世界范围内的非殖民地化等方面作出了重要贡献。尽管联合国并不具有强制其成员国执行公约的军事力量。但它所拥有的对触犯世界安全的国家进行经济制裁的权利使它能在很大程度上影响世界政治局势。

TEXT.English: Originally consigned to the pages of science fiction, the concept of a "space elevator" has begun to attract serious attention in the halls of academia and the space industry itself. The space elevator is a system for cheaply hauling goods and material into space. Once completed, it would quickly replace the current wasteful method of carrying everything up in dangerous and very expensive rockets. [PARAGRAPH:2]The basic concept is simple; a satellite in geosynchronous orbit is connected by cable to a stationery or mobile platform somewhere on Earth's equator. An elevator, or "climber", would ride up and down the cable at a fraction of present costs. [PARAGRAPH:2]There are a number of problems that need to be overcome before such a project could be put in place. For one, the cable would have to be made of a material stronger and lighter than anything yet known. At the moment, carbon nanotubes seem to be the best candidate, but nobody knows how to construct them in quantity, nor yet how to weave them into cable. And even these might not be strong or light enough. [PARAGRAPH:2]However, when considering the many daunting scientific and engineer challenges facing the project, it is quite useful to remember that a far less advanced world figured out how to put a man on the moon a mere ten years after it was first seriously proposed. Many sane and sober people believe that a space elevator will be constructed within this century.
TEXT.Chinese: 起初只是存在于科幻小说里，但现在，“天梯”的构想已经引起了学术界和航天业的注意。天梯是一种向太空运输货物和材料的廉价方式。一旦实现，它将很快取代当前向太空输送物资的危险而昂贵的运载火箭。[PARAGRAPH:2]基本的原理很简单：用一根缆线连接着一颗地球同步轨道卫星和一个地面固定或移动基站。一部电梯，或者“攀登器”将沿这根缆线上下运输物资，这将只花费现在所需运输成本的很小一部分。[PARAGRAPH:2]在这一计划实现前还有很多技术问题需要克服。比如，这根电缆需要用比任何已知的材料都更轻更有强度的材料制成。当前最有希望的材料是碳纳米管，但没人知道如何把它们连接起来，也不知道如何把它们织成缆线。即使能做到，这一材料还是不够轻，不够强。[PARAGRAPH:2]然而，不管这一项目当前面临的科学和技术难题有多少，只要想一想几十年前第一次提出把人类送到月球上去时所面对的技术难题，就会让人觉得信心仍在。许多头脑冷静的人也相信，第一部天梯将在本世纪就会投入使用。

TEXT.English: The Manhattan Project was the code name for a joint project undertaken by the United States, Great Britain and Canada during World War II, the objective being to build an atomic weapon before Germany. While various laboratories had been independently studying nuclear physics for a number of years, the Manhattan Project would be on an entirely different scale; hundreds of the allies' top scientists and engineers were, along with their families, taken to various secret locations around the country where they would stay until the project succeeded. [PARAGRAPH:1]Working conditions were extremely primitive and security was incredibly tight. The United States Army was in overall charge of the Manhattan Project, while the scientists remained in control over the actual research. The scope of the Manhattan Project was immense, and it involved solving some of the most difficult scientific and engineering projects of the day. The men and women, a collection of soldiers and scientists, endured harsh conditions and physical and mental exhaustion, which were compounded by security so tight that many never saw the outside of the base on which they were stationed. They were sustained by their patriotism and by fear of what would happen to them, their families, and their countries if Germany created the bomb first. [PARAGRAPH:1]Eventually, of course, the effort paid off. By the middle of 1945 the US had two working atomic bombs. Germany, the original target, had already surrendered, but Japan was still in the fight. The two weapons were dropped on the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki early in August, and the Japanese Empire surrendered shortly thereafter. [PARAGRAPH:1]From our perspective some decades later, it isn't clear whether the Manhattan Project helped to save the world for democracy or brought it closer to fiery destruction. But the men and women involved believed they were fighting to stop a terrible dictatorship from gaining a new weapon and destroying everything they loved, and they were willing to sacrifice everything to succeed.
TEXT.Chinese: 曼哈顿工程是二次世界大战期间由美国，英国和加拿大共同进行的一项研发计划的代号，其目标是抢在德国之前制造出核武器。虽然在此之前已经有许多实验室独立开展原子物理学研究，但是其规模完全无法与曼哈顿工程相比；数百名同盟国中顶尖的科学家，工程师以及他们的家人都必须集中到与世隔绝的秘密地点，直到计划完成才得以重见天日。[PARAGRAPH:1]当时的工作条件极其艰苦，安全管制也极其严格。曼哈顿工程的管理由美国军方全权负责，科学家们则负责具体的研究工作。曼哈顿工程所涉及的领域非常广阔，需要解决数量极大且难度极高的科学和工程学问题。无数军队士兵和科学家们忍受着艰苦的环境，生理和心理上的疲惫。安全管制是如此的严格，许多人自参加该项目后甚至从未走出秘密基地一步。支持他们继续工作的动力在于他们的爱国热情，以及对于德国人首先造出核武器并危及他们的家人和国家的忧心。[PARAGRAPH:1]当然最终，所有的努力都获得了回报。到1945年中，美国已经拥有了两枚实用的原子弹。而其原定的打击目标德国则已经投降，但是日本仍然在负隅顽抗。于是在八月初，两枚原子弹分别投掷到了广岛和长崎，此后不久日本帝国即宣布投降。[PARAGRAPH:1]在数十年后的今天我们仍然无法确定，曼哈顿工程究竟是拯救了民主世界，还是会最终将其毁灭。但是对于当年的无数工程参与者来说，为了能够制止恐怖独裁者获得新式武器毁灭一切的野心，他们不惜付出任何的代价。

TEXT.English: The Internet is a computer network linked by hard wire, telephony and satellite. These computers share the same language, allowing for the fast transfer of information. Anyone with a computer and a modem (or other hookup) can utilize the Internet to gather information, to broadcast news and opinions, or to shoot at other like-minded folks in virtual reality galleries. In its few years of existence the Internet has dramatically changed the way that information is gathered and transmitted, and the network's full potential cannot be guessed. [PARAGRAPH:1]The Internet was first conceived of in the early 1960s. At that time the discussion was purely theoretical, as the computers, the connections, and the common language did not yet exist. Given that it was the height of the Cold War, neither did the necessary international cooperation. But the idea had many supporters, especially in universities and research labs around the US, and by 1969 four computers located around the country were in communication with each other through ARPA-Net. [PARAGRAPH:1]By the mid-1980s, the core of the network was in place, the communications protocols had been determined, and the Internet was live. By the early 1990s the first Internet language (http) was written and the first browser was published. The World Wide Web was born. [PARAGRAPH:1]The Internet stands today as one of the few great projects constructed largely by individuals rather than by an organization such as a corporation, religion, or government. Various portions of the network were indeed created and funded by the US Department of Defense - but much of it came together organically, built in bits and pieces by professors, scientists and engineers, perhaps less for personal gain than because they thought the "information society" was an idea worth pursuing.
TEXT.Chinese: 因特网是由电线，电话线和卫星线路所联接起来的计算机网络。这些计算机使用同一种协议语言以进行信息的快速转换。任何一个拥有计算机与调制解调器（或其它接入设备）的人都可以利用因特网获取信息，传播新闻与观点，或与持各种相同或不同看法的人们在虚拟现实的走廊里碰面。在其诞生后的几年里，因特网戏剧化地转变了信息获取与传播的方式，而其潜力依然无法预测。[PARAGRAPH:1]因特网的设想最早出现在20世纪60年代早期。那时的讨论是纯理论式的，当时甚至连计算机，线路，和通用语言都还不存在。然而它最初却是由冷战中的思维赋予的，而非为了进行国际合作。但是这个主意有许多支持者，特别是全美的大学与研究所，到了1969年，有四台分散在各地的计算机通过“阿帕网”进行了通讯。[PARAGRAPH:1]到1980年代中期，核心网络已经建成，通讯协议也被规范了，因特网从此诞生。1990年代早期，人们发明了第一种英特网协议语言（HTTP）并且发布了最早的浏览器。万维网随即出现。[PARAGRAPH:1]今天，因特网是少数几个主要由个人建设完成的伟大工程之一，而非出于有组织的实施，比如公司，宗教，政府。网络的一部分的确曾经由美国国防部建立——但绝大部分都是由教授，科学家，工程师一字节一字节、一小块一小块地发展起来的，很少考虑到个人利益，因为他们认为建设信息化社会是值得毕生追求的目标。

TEXT.English: SDI stands for "Strategic Defense Initiative," a research program implemented by the United States in the mid-1980s to provide a ground and space-based shield against incoming nuclear missiles. As proposed, the SDI is a defensive system that will spot incoming intercontinental ballistic missiles, track their courses, and then destroy them before they detonate over US cities. [PARAGRAPH:1]The concept of putting weapons platforms in space has been around for years; in fact the major space powers may have already done so in secret. Some nations have certainly built "satellite killers," satellites designed to destroy enemy satellites, disrupting the opposition's communications and intelligence capabilities. [PARAGRAPH:1]The specific method of incoming missile destruction hasn't been determined. Some have proposed creating powerful x-ray lasers powered by nuclear explosions that would melt the enemy weapons in space; others suggest ground-based anti-missile rockets on the Patriot missile model. [PARAGRAPH:1]To date the project has made little in the way of visible progress, and its future is uncertain. Some people believe that the threat of an incoming nuclear missile is extremely remote, especially when compared to the threat of a nuclear bomb being smuggled into the country by terrorists. Others believe that the entire concept is flawed and that the money would be better spent bribing potential enemies into destroying their ICBMs rather than trying to create a system to shoot them down.
TEXT.Chinese: 战略导弹防御系统（SDI）是一个由美国政府在20世纪80年代中期开始实施的研究项目，它致力于提供地基或空基的防护盾，以抵抗来袭的核导弹。按照预想，该系统能够发现并跟踪来犯的洲际弹道导弹，并将其在美国城市上空引爆前予以摧毁的防御系统。[PARAGRAPH:1]将武器平台置于太空的设想已有多年的历史；事实上或许几个空间强国已经秘密地这么做了。某些国家的确建造了“卫星杀手”，一种设计用来摧毁卫星的卫星，破环对方的通讯和情报能力。[PARAGRAPH:1]摧毁来袭导弹的方法还没决定。有人提议使用X射线来将导弹融化在空间；还有人建议将爱国者导弹改装成地基反导弹火箭。[PARAGRAPH:1]一些人认为来自核导弹的威胁是遥远的，特别与恐怖分子偷带核弹入境的威胁相比。另一些人相信整个计划有严重缺陷，而且与其将钱花在如何射落洲际弹道导弹，还不如想办法贿赂潜在敌人，自行摧毁他们的导弹。

TEXT.English: The Apollo Program was an ambitious project to put a man on the moon. The program was conceived of in the late 1950s by United State officials who were appalled at the Soviet Union's lead in the space race. In 1961, President John F. Kennedy stated before a joint session of Congress, "I believe that this nation should commit itself to achieving the goal, before this decade is out, of landing a man on the Moon and returning him safely to the Earth." [PARAGRAPH:1]There is some speculation about whether President Kennedy himself actually believed in the project; some say that he had serious questions about the cost and scientific feasibility, and that his proposal was mostly a public relations gimmick to raise America's spirits in the face of the perceived Soviet space threat. But America's imagination was fired by the project, and work proceeded with speed. [PARAGRAPH:1]The Apollo Program's managers had to overcome an incredible number of daunting scientific and engineering challenges to succeed. The journey involved many separate phases: ascent from Earth, travel from the Earth to the Moon, descent to the Moon and return to Lunar orbit, followed by the journey back to Earth, and then down to Earth's surface. This required a vehicle with many different capabilities that remained light enough to be put into orbit by the rockets available at the time. (The problem was akin to trying to create a combination submarine, all-terrain vehicle and airplane that could be towed by a Volkswagen Beetle.) [PARAGRAPH:1]That the Apollo Program succeeded and a man walked on the moon in 1969 is an incredible testament to the ingenuity, courage and persistence shown by the dedicated men and women involved.
TEXT.Chinese: 阿波罗计划是一个将人类送上月球的雄心勃勃的计划。这个计划于20世纪50年代后期提出，当时的美国因苏联争得了在太空竞赛中的领导地位而受到了严重的刺激。1961年，约翰·肯尼迪总统在例行参众联席会议上说，“我相信这个国家必须让自己达到这样一个目标，在这个十年结束前，将一个人送上月球，再安全地返回地球。”[PARAGRAPH:1]有一些人猜测肯尼迪总统是否真的相信这个计划；他们说他对于此计划的费用与科学可行性持很大的怀疑态度，并且他的提议更多的是一种公关技巧，意在鼓舞美国人面对苏联空间威胁时的士气与精神。但是美国人的想象力被这计划激发出来了，科学家们开始夜以继日的工作。[PARAGRAPH:1]为了成功完成阿波罗计划，参与者们不得不克服不计其数的令人退缩的科学与工程难题。登月旅程历经多个单独过程：从地球起飞，从地球飞向月球，降落在月球和返回月球轨道，然后再返回地球轨道，最终回到地球表面。这需要一种能完成全部任务的航天器，而且其重量要可以由火箭携往太空轨道。（要了解此问题的难度，可做这样一个类比：建造一艘潜水艇兼全地形越野车还兼飞行器，而且其大小不能超过一辆大众甲壳虫轿车。）[PARAGRAPH:1]最后，阿波罗计划与1969年获得了成功，人类首次得以登上月球，这一奇迹般壮举为所有参与其中的科技与工程专家们的智慧，勇气与坚强努力提供了最好的证明。

TEXT.English: Although humankind has mastered space flight, the concept of interstellar and deep space travel presents many new problems to engineers and physicists. The Exterior Casing of the Space Ship is itself a technological marvel. Designed around a composite system of layered ceramic, zero-gee manufactured aluminum-titanium alloy, and high density polymers, the Exterior Casing is made to withstand both the dangers of debris within star systems and of radiation throughout its travel. Built into the Exterior Casing is also a complex web of electric wiring, capable of carrying a very high positive or negative electromagnetic charge, providing a shield from radiation and literally funneling electromagnetic energy and space borne hydrogen dust into the solar sail where it can be collected and used for further fuel. It is also designed with multiple levels of sensors designed to collect scientific data and to give a clear picture to the navigational computer and to the pilots of what is going on outside of the vehicle. Although this composite design for an Exterior Casing is expensive, the protection and potential scientific information that it affords is well worth the cost of manufacture.
TEXT.Chinese: 虽然人类已经掌握了太空飞行技术，不过星际以及超远距离太空旅行的概念，对于工程师及物理学家来说还是有相当多的问题待解决。飞船的保护性外壳本身就是一个技术杰作。飞船保护壳采用多层陶瓷，以及铝钛合金等高密度复合材料组成，可以确保飞船经得起太空旅行时所遇到的各种危险碎片或是太空射线。保护壳内部还有复杂的电子线路，能够负载高正电荷或高负电荷，用来产生一个能防止辐射线的无形防护罩，并能通过太阳帆收集飞行中所遇到的氢原子，以用做日后的燃料。保护壳还设计有多层感应器，用以搜集科学数据并提供给导航计算机，令驾驶员知晓飞船外部的情形。虽然这样的多重设计是所需花费相当昂贵，但它所提供的安全保护和大量有用信息值得人们付出这样的代价。

TEXT.English: The massive Thrusters are, much like the Engine, designed to function in a myriad of ways. Designed in stages like the Engines, the Thrusters channel the exhaust used to propel the Space Ship through all of its phases of travel. In the initial phase, the external booster rockets channel their fuel through the Thrusters array until they run out of fuel, at which point they are jettisoned. After that, the powerful electromagnets built into the Thrusters help accelerate the charged particles of the ion drive to near the speed of light, providing a great deal of thrust for the Space Ship.[PARAGRAPH:1]Finally, in the last stages of travel, the Thrusters are responsible for maneuvering the Space Ship into the planet's gravity well and providing a counter thrust to slow the vessel to a manageable velocity to settle into a geo-synchronous orbit. In order to fulfill all of these functions, the Thrusters array had to be capable of the ultra-sensitive duty of accelerating high energy ions as well as be able to handle the hundreds of thousands of pounds of thrust produced by the solid fuel boosters.[PARAGRAPH:1]The engineers who designed the Thrusters were able to fulfill both of these functions as well as making them articulated to allow for maneuverability that is remarkable considering the mass and projected velocities of the craft.
TEXT.Chinese: 巨大的飞船推进器外观与应用于其他运输工具的各种喷气式引擎差不多，设计原理也类似。飞船推进器通过喷射方式来推进太空飞船，以完成航程的各个阶段。在开始阶段，由外挂副燃料箱向各组助推火箭提供燃料，直到燃料用尽时就抛弃。在此之后，再由内置推进器以强大的电磁力加速离子束，使其接近光速，这为飞船提供了绝大部份的继航动力。[PARAGRAPH:2]在航程的最后阶段，推进器负责调整飞船进入行星引力圈，并提供反向推力以缓和速度，使飞船能安然进入行星同步轨道。为了实现所有这些功能，推进器组必须具备加速高能离子的高度感应能力，又要能够操控由固态燃料推进器所产生的数十万磅的推力。[PARAGRAPH:1]设计推进器的工程师需要保证其能够同时实现这两种功能，并使其能够为质量巨大，速度极高的飞船提供足够的机动能力。

TEXT.English: The Space Ship Engine is actually a four part launch vehicle, designed to enable the Space Ship to complete its journey both within the high gravity space-time bends surrounding star systems and through the vast emptiness of deep space that separates our star from Alpha Centauri. Its first stage is the external booster rockets, which, much like the terrestrially launched shuttles of the late twentieth century, are solid fuel boosters and are jettisoned when they are no longer needed. They are crucial to build the initial impulse which will carry the Space Ship into Jupiter's gravity well, giving it the energy to slingshot to Uranus and then out into deep space. The second part to the Engine is the Space Ship's solar sail, which was designed both to use the radiation emitted from our sun and Jupiter for propulsion and to collect atomic particles for further future fuel and materials. The third part of the Engine array is the ion drive, which will harness both nuclear power and collected hydrogen to propel the craft through deep space, channeling high energy particles through the Thrusters. The fourth and most externally obvious component is the hydrogen solid fuel rocket, which will be used in the final phases of the Space Ship's travel to place it in orbit around Alpha Centauri's planetary system.
TEXT.Chinese: 太空飞船的发动机实际上是由四部分所组成的，其设计能使飞船顺利穿透星系周围由强大引力所造成的时空扭曲，并跨越阻隔在我们的恒星与半人马星系间浩瀚而空旷的星际空间。在第一阶段进行工作的是外部助推器，与二十世纪后期的航天飞机所用的推进器类似，这是使用固态燃料的推进器，并在其完成使命后就自动抛弃。它们能提供足够的动力，使飞船进入木星引力范围，通过借力抛射穿越天王星进入深空。第二部分是飞船的太阳帆，它依靠太阳及木星的辐射能推进，并收集原子微粒作为未来的燃料及物资。第三部分则是离子推进器，通过重核裂变或氢核聚变反应产生能量加速高能粒子，驱动飞船穿越深空。第四部分，也是飞船外部最为明显的组件即固态氢燃料火箭，用于飞船最后阶段的旅程，使飞船进入环绕半人马座阿尔法星的轨道。

TEXT.English: Built entirely in space and for space travel, the Space Ship is a marvel of human technology. The Docking Bay module allows for the transfer of personnel and materials both during the initial loading of the Space Ship as well as during its final orbit, during which it will be converted to a Space Station for the first phase of the colonization and terraforming process. The Docking Bay module also holds the RCV Manned Shuttle, the main travel and transit vehicle for the Space Ship occupants, as well as providing access for the engineers to the exterior of the Space Ship during space walks. The Docking Bay is in essence a large air lock with a door large enough to release the RCV, flanked by a pair of smaller air locks for transferal of small teams of individuals. The Docking Bay also has large magnetic locks, allowing the Space Ship to join to the International Space Station prior to its departure during the final phases of supply loading before launching from Earth's orbit for its interstellar trip.
TEXT.Chinese: 作为人类科学技术的巅峰之作，太空飞船完全在太空轨道上建造和组装。飞船对接舱组件可在飞船的初期加载及最后入轨全过程中作为人员与货物的传送通道，在到达目标轨道后，它将被改装为一座太空站，为行星移民及地形改造的最初阶段提供相关服务。对接舱组件还配有数架太空梭（RCV），作为船员的轨道交通工具，并辅助太空工程师在飞船周围进行太空漫步。对接舱的主要结构就是一组气闸，包括足够容纳RCV进出的大型通道，以及用于宇航员进出的小型通道。对接舱还配有更大的电磁闸门，用于连接飞船和国际空间站完成最后阶段的补给工作，然后飞离地球轨道开始星际航行。

TEXT.English: The command and control center of the Space Ship, the Cockpit component is the brain of the vessel. Ergonomically designed for the comfort of the pilots, the Cockpit holds all of the advanced navigation and systems control computers necessary for interstellar travel and interplanetary colonization as well as providing for all of the long-term necessities of its occupants. A fully encased component, the Cockpit has no unshielded area, completely encasing the occupants in a protective shell of titanium, ceramic, and an electromagnetic repulsion system to shed unwanted radiation. It utilizes the latest in holographic technology for star chart navigation, heads up displays for a 360 degree range of vision around the Space Ship, and the most advanced sensors available for collision detection and avoidance.[PARAGRAPH:1]The crowning jewel of the Cockpit component, however, is the advanced CAM Computer System, an artificial intelligence system designed to evaluate the potential dangers of deep space flight that may be encountered in the regions that no human has ever before penetrated. The CAM System continually monitors radiation fields and particle positions, judging the best way to deal with any potential threat and alerting the pilots in case of an emergency. The CAM system also helps keep the pilots entertained, having full access to the libraries of the Planetary Party lounge and being the most advanced Chess computer in the known galaxy.
TEXT.Chinese: 飞船驾驶舱作为指令控制中心，是整艘飞船的大脑。驾驶舱采用完善的人体工程学设计，以尽可能让驾驶员感到舒适，其中配备有各种先进的导航系统和计算机系统，以满足星际旅行及外星移民全过程的各种需要。驾驶舱自成一体，具有完善的安全保护设施，其外壳由钛及陶瓷复合材料制成，并由无形的电磁效应保护罩反射危险的太空辐射。驾驶舱利用最新的全息技术来显示星际导航图，能同时完整显示360度视角，并装有最新型的碰撞侦测与规避探测器。[PARAGRAPH:1]驾驶舱中最核心的组件则是最先进的超级计算机系统（CAM），该系统能够自动分析超长距离星际航行中可能遭遇到的各种潜在危险。CAM系统通过持续监视辐射场以及宇宙粒子的位置，判断出能够规避潜在威胁的最佳航线，并在遇到紧急状况时及时警告驾驶员。CAM系统还能为驾驶员提供休闲娱乐，它拥有飞船生活舱信息资料库的完整读取权限，也是全星系最聪明的国际象棋大师。

TEXT.English: Essential to the sustenance of human life are food, water, air, and heat, and the Life Support System provides all of these things. Recycling is the key to the Space Ship's Life Support System, and no organic component is left to waste in the vessel. Computers control the collection and recycling of waste, which is injected into large vats of algae which consume the waste or processed into fertilizer for the Space Ship hydroponics garden. Both the algae and the garden provide food and oxygen for the colonists as well as for their livestock, which consist of fish, shrimp, and a particularly hearty (and tasty) breed of Peruvian mountain llama.[PARAGRAPH:1]Extra oxygen is processed in the air filtration system, which electrically divides water into hydrogen and oxygen molecules and separates them for oxygen and fuel uses. Excess heat produced by the Fuel Cells is also absorbed into steam pipes, which are used to keep the interior of the vessel warm and to separate pure water out of waste water to a 99.44%% purity.[PARAGRAPH:1]Extraplanetary travel has never before been attempted on this scale, and the Life Support System has been carefully crafted to provide indefinitely for the needs of the colonists as well as giving them a basis for redeveloping a food chain on the eventual planet of colonization.
TEXT.Chinese: 维持人类生命的必需品有食物、水、空气及热能，而服务舱则提供了这些必需品。循环利用则是飞船上生命维持系统的关键所在，在星际旅行中没有任何有机物是可以被轻易浪费的。在飞船中，必须由电脑控制，归集并再利用这些废弃物，把这些废弃物注入到一个含有大量藻类的分解槽之中，将它们制成肥料然后用在飞船上无土栽培的植物园之中。这些藻类以及植物也提供了开拓者及养殖的动物维生必须的氧气，这些动物包括鱼、虾以及特别美味的秘鲁山地驼马等。[PARAGRAPH:2]多余的氧气会被空气过滤系统电解成氢，氧分子而又将氢气用在燃料用途之上。燃料电池产生的多余热量会被用于产生蒸汽并通过管线运送，使得飞船内可以保持一定的温度，最终分离出99.44%纯度的淡水。[PARAGRAPH:1]超远距离的星系旅行是过去从未尝试过的冒险，因此生命维持系统必须仔细设计、确保可靠，此系统也是提供星际开拓者在最后阶段的行星殖民时重建食物链的一个重要基石。

TEXT.English: With a journey predicted to take decades, if not centuries, one of the most important considerations of the engineers was the aging of the crew. Recent advances in cryogenics and chemical therapy have enabled scientists to chemically slow the metabolic process to a virtual standstill, which enables the scientists to then deep freeze the body without harm. Sensors regulate the zero-oxygen environment to ensure that the colonists will be kept as safe as possible, and a special warming system utilizing broad spectrum electromagnetic radiation is used to quickly and safely restore warmth to the body.[PARAGRAPH:1]The radiation also has the effect of breaking down the chemical agents that slow the colonists' metabolism, making them able to be thawed out in a matter of seconds and fully aware in a little over a minute. This is essential to the survival of the craft in a situation in which the computer is unable to determine a course of action and a pilot or navigator must be roused to assess the danger, or in a situation in which a technician must be roused to effect repairs.[PARAGRAPH:1]This system has been used very effectively in tests on pigs and monkeys, and it has been shown that such animals in deep cryogenic sleep have been able to be roused after three years with absolutely no visible side effects. A couple of military volunteers have also been frozen to test the system, but only for a matter of weeks. Although scientists have not yet tested the effects of long-term freezing on human beings, they are completely confident that there will not be any problems with the Stasis Chamber on the Space Ship.[PARAGRAPH:1]Completely confident.
TEXT.Chinese: 如果按照预期，超远距离星际旅行需要花费数十年甚至上百年的时间，工程师们要考虑的一个重要问题就是飞船上人员年龄的老化。采用最新的低温化疗技术，可以使人的新陈代谢近乎停滞，这样科学家就可以将人体进行低温冷冻，而不会造成任何伤害。近乎无氧的环境也让这些星际移民安全地维持生命状态，而特殊的加温系统的射线则可以让他们的身体在未来迅速而安全地复苏。[PARAGRAPH:1]这种射线同时也可立即中和那些减缓新陈代谢的化学物质，使他们能够在数分钟后就能够恢复正常的作息。这项技术对太空旅行是非常重要的，例如在电脑失灵时，驾驶员必须要亲自去处理这些危险时；或者是飞船必须进行人工维护时。这个系统已经用猪以及猴子测试过，而且成效显著，进入低温休眠的这些动物们在三年后成功苏醒，并且没有任何负作用。一群军人也自愿成为这个系统的测试者，不过仅仅进行了为期数周的测试。虽然科学家们并没有经过长期测试，不过他们认为在太空飞船配备休眠舱将不会有任何问题。[PARAGRAPH:1]科学家们对此有完全的信心……
